editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: OBSERVATIONS Upon the PRESENT STATE OF TURKY.
div.p:
THe whole Power of the Ottoman Empire, menacing a con≈øiderable part of Europe at this time, with a mo≈øt di≈ømal De≈øolation, ‚Ä¢ he Maps of tho≈øe Countries being mo≈øt in ‚Ä¢ ogue, and que≈øtions Concerning the Policy, Religions, and Manners of the Turks having ‚Ä¢ ow the greate≈øt ≈øhare in all Di≈øcour≈øes and Conver≈øations; I thought a Compendium of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e pre≈øent State would not be un≈øea≈øonable, ‚Ä¢ r unwelcom to the World, but would ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ntribute both to others and my own En
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tainment.

Tho' this undertaking does ≈øeem to be of a greater extent, and to require a larger Bulk, than the≈øe ≈øheets will admit off; yet I que≈øtion not, to give a full and ≈øatisfactory account of the Policy of the Turks, and therein of the fundamental Maxims of their Government: Of the ≈øtrength and numbers of their Militia, of the Civil Offices and their Revenues, with a Relation of the Seraglio, and all thereunto belonging, adding the Model and Con≈øtitution of their Religion, with the Articles of their Faith, and the Memoires and Hi≈øtory of the pre≈øent Grand Seigniors Life unto this day. if I perform this ≈øo well, as to content the Curio≈øity and Speculation of the Age upon tho≈øe points, I ≈øhall have ≈øufficiently flattered my Ambition in having been able to furni≈øh any thing towards the publick ≈øatisfaction.

So agreeable a Scene as the pourtraict of Turky does afford, cannot be too often repre≈øented; that variety of Cu≈øtomes, which how Barbarous ≈øoever our Opticks may repre≈øent to us, being no le≈øs pretending to Civility than our own, tho' in an other Garb. And indeed it has ≈øeldom been known that where the People and the Government have been rich, Arts, and Civility have been long wanting and ab≈øent, the one attending generall ‚Ä¢
upon the other. Wherefore if this Land-≈øhip of the State of Turky be but con≈øidered with unprejudiced Eyes, it will undoubtedly appear in other Colours than we commonly be≈øtow upon that Nation.

div.head: CHAP. II. The fundamental Maximes of the Turki≈øh Policy.
div.p:
THe fir≈øt Grand Maxime of the Turki≈øh Policy, is an entire and ab≈øolute Submi≈ø≈øion and Obedience of the Subjects to the Will of their Prince, this ab≈øolute re≈øignation to the Plea≈øure and Command of their Soveraign is in≈øtilled into the Turks, indeed rather as a Principle of Religion, than a meer Politick Maxime; ≈øuch Care being taken in the Education both of the Youth of the Seraglio who ≈øtand fair and are the Nur≈øery for the Principal Offices of the Empire and of all the other Subjects of the Grand Seigniors Dominions, as to infu≈øe into them this O
‚Ä¢ inion, that it is highly Meritorious and a ‚Ä¢ ind of holy Martyrdom to dye by either the ‚Ä¢ and or Command of their Prince; in≈øomuch that it would be no wonder among≈øt ‚Ä¢ em to ≈øee whole Armies at his lea≈øt beck
plunge them≈øelves into Aby≈ø≈øes, make Bridgges with Piles of their Bodies for him to pa≈øs over Rivers, and only for his Diver≈øion kill and butcher one another. This ≈øubjection the Turki≈øh Machiavels look upon to have been a main Engin to the Encrea≈øe and Enlargement of their Dominions, and fancy the ≈ølackning this Di≈øcipline, and the Cabals in the Mini≈øtry under ≈øome of the late Emperours, has been the occa≈øion of tho≈øe Revolts and Di≈øorders which have happened in that State.

The next is, the Princes preferring ≈øuch Per≈øons to the principal Charges of the Court and Empire, as he can advance without Envy, and de≈øtroy without Peril: And indeed nothing could be more for the intere≈øt of a Prince than the conduct of the Ottoman Court in this point; for none are admitted into the Grand Seigniors Service, but ≈øuch as have had their Breeding and Education from him, and by that means have imbibed ≈øuch Principles from their Infancy as tend wholly to the real Thankfulne≈øs for the Bread and Nouri≈øhment they have received, and a kind of Religious Awe and Veneration to his Per≈øon. Be≈øides, as the≈ø ‚Ä¢ Per≈øons are con≈øtantly ≈øuch as are taken in War or by Pyracy from Chri≈øtian Parents they remain without tho≈øe u≈øual ≈øupport
which the common Intere≈øt of a Family and Alliances does afford. Moreover, the Sentiments they in≈øpire into tho≈øe Per≈øons are ≈øuch as nouri≈øh and foment a dete≈øtation and abhorrence of their Parents Opinions, and ≈øpurr them on to the venturing their lives, their All to reduce them to the ≈øame Belief.

The Parity of Per≈øons which is ob≈øerved throughout All the Turki≈øh Dominions, is al≈øo without que≈øtion one of the main ≈øecurities of the Turki≈øh ≈øway, for all are here equal and nothing but merit does advance People to the Mini≈øtry and places of State. Thus all Offices being in the immediate di≈øpo≈øal of the Emperour, and not to be obtained by the Factions of Grandees, who might divert the Peoples Eyes from off the Court, and by degrees tempt and delude them≈øelves into Rebellion, they make their addre≈ø≈øes directly to the Grand Seignior, as to the true ≈øource of their Promotions and Fortunes. And as this Parity makes all the People court only their Princes favour, ≈øo it prevents any thoughts of an In≈øurrection, or off ca≈øting of that Yoke of Tyranny, ≈øcorning ba≈øely to follow and promote the Intere≈øt of tho≈øe who are but their Equalls. Thus the Subjects in Turky have nothing Hereditary, all their Honours and Places determining
with their lives, none receiving any Glory from Illu≈øtriou≈øne≈øs of extraction, but only from the Princes Favour and Bounty, which is in no wi≈øe claim'd or le≈ø≈øen'd by greatne≈øs of Birth, which here rather creates jealou≈øy and danger, than favour and advantage: By the≈øe means People are Studious to qualify them≈øelves for Offices, which Per≈øonal Merits render them Candidates for; and as the Grand Seignior is here the Admini≈øtratour to all dead Men's E≈øtates, Parents have not their thoughts ≈øo intent of heaping up Riches for an Inheritance to their Children, as they are to Capacitate them for their Princes Service. And this De≈øtruction of all Nobility, cutting off all ≈øucce≈ø≈øion to Riches, Offices and the Government, but in the direct Ottomen line, does certainly pre≈øerve the Body of the Empire free from Faction and Rebellion. Whereas the Rich and powerful Governments of many Provinces which lye far remote from the Seat of the Empire, might tempt their Governours to a Rebellion, had they the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and ≈øupport which an ancient and an Illu≈øtrious Extraction does afford. But as their Ba≈øhaws come of unknown Parents, are continued but for a ≈øhort time in tho≈øe forreign Governments, are Strangers in the Countries they ≈øway, have no ancient Blood
and E≈øtates to entitle them Heirs to the Succe≈ø≈øion, no Relations, Kindred or Alliances to ≈øecond, pro≈øecute or revenge their Quarrels, or to create Kindne≈øs or Compa≈ø≈øion in the People to concern them≈øelves in their behalf; ≈øo are the≈øe Mini≈øters deprived of all means, opportunities or po≈ø≈øibility, of promoting any Intere≈øt of their own above that of their Soveraigns: this it is has rendred all Emotions that have been, and ≈øometimes will be in all Empires of ≈øuch ≈øhort continuance as Turky; this it is that ≈øuffers the greate≈øt Subjects in tho≈øe Dominions to be cut off according to the Princes Caprice, without rai≈øing the lea≈øt Murmurs among≈øt the People, who gaze upon ≈øuch Spectacles without concern, or if they Create any Motions in them they are only ≈øuch as afford plea≈øure, which they receive in ≈øeeing ≈øuch Examples of Fortunes Uncon≈øtancy in the World. But this ≈øeverity in the Turki≈øh Policy does not only extend to the Ba≈øhaws and great Men, but to the very Ottoman Family it ≈øelf, who are ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed with greater ≈øtrictne≈øs than all others, and are debarred all Wealth and Offices. Thus by the fundamental Laws of the Empire, the Children of a Grand Seigniors Daughter married to a Ba≈øhaw, are not capable of any Office in the State, but if by favour this is at any time di≈øpen≈øed
with, they can never attain to any higher Preferment than that of a Capugiba≈øhee, which is one of the Porters of the Grand Seigniors Gate. Nay, it is ≈øo great a Crime to be allyed to the Royal Family, that it is almo≈øt Trea≈øon in tho≈øe of this Race to name it, nor is there in Turky but one Branch of this Line of any account or e≈øteem, and that is the Off≈øpring of Sultan Ibrahim, who was a Son of the Grand Seigniors Si≈øter, and marryed to a Sultana (and are ≈øaid to be of the Race of the Tartars) thus coming only by the Womans ≈øide the le≈øs notice is taken of their Blood. Nor had this Family ≈øub≈øi≈øted to this day, had it not been for this extraordinary Prudence and Di≈øcretion of its conduct in all the Revolutions of the Turki≈øh Government, never a≈øpiring to Offices, nor medling with affaires of State, but living contentedly and with out O≈øtentation upon a ≈ømall yearly revenue of about 70000 Dollars.

The Turks do look upon as one Cau≈øe of the Con≈øervation of their Dominions, their laying wa≈øt and de≈øolating their own Provinces that lye the farthe≈øt remote from the Seat of their Empire, and by this means they think to enervate and di≈øpirit the People, and bring them more within the reach and compa≈øs of Authority. And indeed it is
≈øeldom known that any Rebellions do ari≈øe under the Turki≈øh ≈øway, tho' in the remote≈øt parts of A≈øia; and the≈øe few that have been ≈øeen, have with ca≈øe been calmed and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed for the Male-contents and re≈øtle≈øs Spirits find no ≈øhelter in tho≈øe Parts, being ≈øtripped of their Fortifications and Retreats in the Woods and Forre≈øts, and the Rebels thereby expo≈øed to the pur≈øuits of an irritated Prince. And this it is that con≈øtrains the great men of that Empire to deliver them≈øelves up without more ado to undergo Puni≈øhment and Death at the Will of their Soveraign, ≈øeeing they have no means of flight, nor no place of refuge le≈øt in Countries, that are laid wholly wa≈øt and afford no ≈øu≈øtenance or ≈øupport. Be≈øides this di≈øpeopling, di≈ømantling, and thus de≈øolating the Country, is attended with this other advantage, that no Forreign Enemy can with a Land Army make any Inva≈øion into it with advantage, for the de≈øolation of it renders it uncapable of furni≈øhing any Provi≈øions, and that there it is ea≈øily de≈øtroyed by the Grand Seigniors own Subjects, and for an Army to bring Ammunition, and Provi≈øion along with it ≈øufficient for ≈øuch an Expedition, is a thing almo≈øt impo≈ø≈øible. Neverthele≈øs the immediate Frontier Places of their new Conque≈øts the Turks
take always Care to fortify, and to garni≈øh and ≈øtrengthen with Colonies of their own People.

Now as the Turki≈øh Expeditions are like a Torrent, which bears all down before them ≈øo it is a point of their Policy when they have made a Conque≈øt of any con≈øiderable Country to ≈øtrike up a Peace immediately, that ≈øo they may have time to ≈øettle and confirm them≈øelves in their new Acqui≈øitions, well knowing, that what they have ≈øo ha≈øtily overrun, is again to be as ea≈øily recovered, and that the ≈øtream of ≈øuch inundations is as rapid in the Ebb as in the Flux.

The frequent Change of Officers, the degrading of ≈øome and exalting of others, is thought to tend very much to the welfare of the Ottoman Empire, for hereby tho≈øe Sparks are deprived of the means of rivetting them≈øelves in the Peoples Affections, or of fomenting any mutiny or alteration in the State: Be≈øides as all Offices are here purcha≈øed at very dear Rates, every Ba≈øhaw of Grand Caire or of Babylon paying three or four hundred thou≈øand Dollars for their Commi≈ø≈øion; others two, others one hundred thou≈øand, according as their places are more or le≈øs con≈øiderable, and this Money they are con≈øtrained to take up at intere≈øt
paying forty or fifty per cent. annually and oftentimes more, ≈øo that they are forced to ≈øqueeze and fleece the People for the reimbur≈øing them≈øelves again, clear their engagements, and bribe and purcha≈øe the Favour and Protection of the Minions of the Court. Neverthele≈øs this ≈øtands them in little ≈øtead, for when they have pretty well glutted them≈øelves with their Exorbitant Exactions, and that the People begin to bawle out loud again≈øt the Tyranny and Oppre≈ø≈øion of tho≈øe Mini≈øters, they are pre≈øently offered up a Sacrifice to their Furies, and tho≈øe va≈øt E≈øtates and Ma≈øs of Trea≈øure which they had ≈øo unju≈øtly heaped, confi≈øcated to the Grand Seigniors u≈øe, who only be≈øtows on their Po≈øterity what he in his Bounty thinks fitting. Nor are the≈øe Harpies of Mini≈øters the only Per≈øons liable to the ≈øeverity of the Turki≈øh Government, tho≈øe who are the Favourites of the People being no le≈øs expo≈øed to the keenne≈øs of the Ottoman ≈øway, which looks upon Popularity as an unpardonable Crime. But then the≈øe Darling Officers are not di≈øpatched into the other World after the ≈øame manner as tho≈øe publick Pe≈øts, who are executed in Triumph, but the others are cajoled with all manner of fair treatment, the Grand Seigniors Umbrage is di≈ø≈øembled and they perhaps
pre≈øented with a Hor≈øe, a Sword, a Sable Ve≈øt, or a Commi≈ø≈øion for ≈øome more honourable and advantagious Government, until they have got them into ≈øuch places, that the Executioner doing his orders by ≈ølipping the Bow-≈øtring about their Necks, cannot create any combu≈øtion nor hazard the publick Peace. Thus does Turky afford the fruitful Landskip of the uncon≈øtancy and mutability of Humane Grandeur that ever any other Country did, one moment ≈øeeing one of the≈øe Meteors ≈øhining in all the ≈øplendour, pomp, lu≈øtre and magnificence imaginable, and the next fall unpittied, barbarou≈øly put to death, his body thrown into the Dirt of a forreign and unknown Countrey, without any ≈øolemnity of Funeral or Monument, but no ≈øooner in the Grave than his memory is forgotten.

But now I think 'twould not be all together improper to ≈øet down ≈øome of tho≈øe Religious Arts and Maximes whereby the Turki≈øh Faith has and is propogated, e≈øpecially ≈øince their Law has that influence upon Affairs of State, and ≈øo contrived for the honour and profit of the Sovereign; but for that purpo≈øe I ≈øhall not need to look back ≈øo far as to give an account of its fir≈øt taking root or e≈øtabli≈øhment, nor that Mahomets Law was an hodge-podg of Judai≈øme,
Chry≈øtianity, and Pagani≈øm, nor of his nicking for lucky a juncture, as when the greate≈øt Politicians of the Age were employed in framing a Model of an Eccle≈øia≈øtical Monarchy, they and the Divines bu≈øied in healing the Wounds, which the Here≈øies of Arius and Ne≈øtorius had made in the Church, nor ≈øhall I ≈øpeak of the ≈øtupidity and blocki≈øhne≈øs of the Age and Country he fir≈øt ≈øet up in, and ≈øo the more ea≈øy to be impo≈øed upon by his fal≈øe and pretended Miracles, giving out he was ≈øent by God to give a new Law to Mankind, and that he was to reduce the World by force of Arms to his Obedience; that as Chri≈øt was greater than Mo≈øes, ≈øo was he greater than Chri≈øt and the la≈øt of the Prophets; that he had Communication with the Angel Gabriel for two years together that he lived in a Cave, who delivered to him and helped him to compile the Alchoran, tho' it was done by the help of Sergius the Monk; keeping a Pidgeon which he had taught to feed out of his Ear, he pretended it was the Holy Gho≈øt, whom he conver≈øed with and who in≈øtructed him in the Divine Precepts. Whenever he was in fits of the Falling-≈øickne≈øs, to which he was extreamly ≈øubject, he gave out that they were holy and prophetical Trances, with many other ≈øuch like fopperies, and mad-vi≈øionary tales, too tedious
here to relate. Wherefore we will only take a ≈øhort view of the practices now in u≈øe with them for the in≈øinuating and promoting the Rites, Doctrines and Laws of the Turki≈øh Religion.

The fir≈øt was a Toleration of other Religions, e≈øpecially cajoling the Chri≈øtians and their Te ‚Ä¢ ents, owning Chri≈øt to be a Prophet, and a greater too than Mo≈øes; that Mary conceived by the ≈ømell of a Ro≈øe; that the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin was free from Original ≈øin, and the Temptations of the Devil; that Chri≈øt was the Word of God and is ≈øo ≈øtiled in the Alchoran, and cured Di≈øea≈øes, rai≈øed the dead, and workt many miracles, and that his Di≈øciples did the like by his power, hardly any of them ever ≈øpeaking of our Saviour but with Veneration and Reverence, but will warmly deny his Pa≈ø≈øion, ≈øaying it were an Impiety to believe that God who loved and had conferred ≈øo much Power, and ≈øo many Graces on Chri≈øt, ≈øhould ≈øo far di≈øhonour him, as to deliver him into the Hands of the Jews, who were the wor≈øt and mo≈øt ≈øcorned of Men, or to the Death of the Cro≈øs which was the mo≈øt vile and infamous of all puni≈øhments; for being, as they ≈øay, led toward the place of Execution, God not permitting ≈øo ba≈øe a People to put to Death ≈øo holy a Prophet (for they
confe≈øs that he never ≈øinned) did a≈ø≈øume him into Heaven: when mi≈øt and ≈øought by the Souldiers in the throng, they laid hold of one of the Judges that had condemned him, who re≈øembled him much in favour and proportion, telling him that he ≈øhould not e≈øcape from them again; and ≈øo not believing what≈øoever he ≈øaid, executed him in his Room. By ≈øuch like Baits and Artifices as the≈øe, and puni≈øhing ≈øeverely all tho≈øe who Bla≈øpheme the name of Chri≈øt, they think to decoy and invite over to their belief the unwary Chri≈øtians.

Toleration, as I ≈øaid, being one of the fir≈øt Traps that was laid for the Profe≈ø≈øours of others Creeds, they have improved it to this, among the other advantages of ≈øeducing and perverting the People that dwell among them, that as they allow of Churches and Hou≈øes of Devotion in places where they have been anciently founded, but admit not of holy buildings on new Foundations; they may repair the old coverings and roofs, but cannot lay a ≈øtone in a new Place con≈øecrated to Divine Service, nor if fire or any accident de≈øtroy the ≈øuper≈øtructure can it be re-edifyed, or any new ≈øtrength added to the Foundation, wherewith to underprop for an other building. Thus in time all the Churches in the Ottoman Empire mu≈øt of
nece≈ø≈øity fall to utter ruine, as many have already done, ≈øo that ≈øeeing the Turki≈øh Laws do not permit Chri≈øtian Churches to be re≈øtored, Chri≈øtianity in time will be aboli≈øhed in tho≈øe Dominions, unle≈øs it be the good Will of Heaven otherwi≈øe to ordain it.

Neither are their Laws concerning Chri≈øtian Children le≈øs conducing to the propagating Chri≈øtianity, for if a man turn Turk, his Children under the age of fourteen years, tho' educated with other Principles, mu≈øt be forced to the ≈øame Per≈øwa≈øion, Men that ≈øpeak again≈øt the Mahometan Law, that have ra≈øhly promi≈øed at a time of Di≈øtraction or Drunkenne≈øs to become Turks, orhave had a carnal knowledge of a Turki≈øh Woman, mu≈øt either become Martyrs or Apo≈øtates; be≈øides many other ≈øubtleties they have to entrap the Souls of Chri≈øtians with the niceties and entanglements of their Law.

Another point of the Mahometan Policy is for the promoting of their Sect, not to deliver up any City Town or Fortre≈øs where Mo≈øques or other Religious Hou≈øes of their per≈øwa≈øion have been once built, and where Mahometani≈øm has been profe≈ø≈øed; thus the Turk has no ≈øooner ≈øet footing in a Town, but that he falls immediately to erecting of Mo≈øques and Temples, and thereby lays an

THe Turks are generally well complexioned, of goodly Statures, full Bodies, and ≈øutably proportioned; they ≈øuffer no hair about them, but a lock on their Crown, and what grows on their Faces; for their Beards they wear at full length, as a mark of gravity and of freedom, the Slaves in the Levant being ≈øhaved, and the Chri≈øtians ridiculed who ≈øo un-man them≈øelves by taking off their Beards. It is a badge of their Religion to wear white Sha≈øhes and Turbants on their Heads, and they di≈øtingui≈øh their Vocations and Quality by their foldings and their ≈øize. Next to their Skin they wear a Calico Smock, with large Sleeves longer than their Arms; under this a pair of Calico Drawers, reaching to their Anckles, with Yellow or Red ≈ølip-Shoes, picked at the Toe, and plated on the Soal: Over all they wear a half ≈øleeved Coat girt unto them with a Sha≈øh or Towel: their Neck all bare; and this is their Summer Garb within Doors. But when they go abroad they
wear over all Gownes, ≈øome with wide half Sleeves, others with long hanging Sleeves buttoned before, and by the meaner People another Fa≈øhion, reaching but a little below the Knee, with hanging-Sleeves not much longer than the Arm, and open before, but all of them ungathered in the Shoulders. In the Winter they wear a kind of Breeches or Drawers of Cloth which about the ≈ømall of their Leg are ≈øowed to ≈øhort ≈ømooth Buskins of Leather without Soals, fit for the Foot, as the Glove for the Hand; lining their Gowns with Fur, as they do their Coats; having then the Sleeves (or quilted Wa≈øtecotes under them) reaching clo≈øe to their Wri≈øts. They wear no Gloves, they wear long Handkerchiefs at their Girdles, ≈øome of great Value, and admirable well wrought, the Modes never change in Turky, no more than they do in Spain, nor is there any great difference in the make of the Cloaths of mean People and tho≈øe of Quality, only that they wear Cloth of Ti≈ø≈øue, of Gold and Silver, Velvet, Scarlet, Satin, Damask, Camlets, lined with Sables and other co≈øtly Furres, and with Martins, Squirrils, Foxes, and Coney-skins according to their ≈øeveral Qualities. But the common wear is Violet Cloth, they retain ≈øtill the Antient cu≈øtome of pre≈øenting
Change of Rayment. The Clergy go much in Green, it being Mahomets Colour, and tho≈øe of his Po≈øterity and Kindred wear Green ≈øha≈øhes, and are called Emers, which is Lord, the Women in like manner wearing al≈øo ≈øomething of Green upon their Heads to be known. A Chri≈øtian is not allowed to wear Green, if he does out of ignorance, he ≈øhall be ≈øoundly beaten, and his Cloaths torn off his Back. In the City they have no Arms, only tuck under their Girdle a crooked Knife of the bigne≈øs of a Dagger, in ≈øheaths of Mettal, all be≈øet with Gemms and precious Stones to a con≈øiderable value. They are upright in their Gate, lofty in their Demeanour with an elated Countenance. The greate≈øt ≈øign of Love and Honour is among them to take a Per≈øon by the Hand, and lay it to ones Forehead; they lay their Hands on their Bo≈øomes in their familiar Salutations, bending their Bodies a little; but in their re≈øpects to Per≈øons of Illu≈øtrious Quality, they bow to the very Ground, and ki≈øs the Hem of his Garment. of their Publick Buildings) once or twice a Week, but perfuming their Beards and the in≈øide of their Turbants with Amber, they are ≈øo ≈øuper≈øtitious in their wa≈øhings, that they fancy the lea≈øt Excrement upon their Garments is a Polution. They are but a ≈øhort while at Table, and have ≈øooner dined then we can eat a Di≈øh of Broth. As ≈øoon as Dinners over they wrap up their Sofra or Leather Carpet, their Table being a round Board, ≈øtanding on a Foot not pa≈øt a Foot high, and brim'd like a Charger; the Di≈øhes have Feet like ≈øtanding Bowls, and are ≈øo ≈øet one upon an other, that you may eat of each without removing of any, tho' commonly they have neither Tables nor Stools in their Hou≈øes but ≈øit cro≈øs'd legg'd on the Floor at thei ‚Ä¢ Victuals, all in a ring. Their Hou≈øes are generally made of Brick baked in the Sun, ar ‚Ä¢ low and mean, which is to be a≈øcribed to the Peoples having no properties of thei ‚Ä¢ owne, and therefore Care not to ≈øpend either their Trea≈øure or their time in building what they cannot tran≈ømit to their Po≈øterity nay which they them≈øelves may be outed „Äà‚óä„Äâ the very next Moment. Now tho' the Mahometans have ≈øome Rules of Architectur ‚Ä¢ for the above mentioned rea≈øon they neve ‚Ä¢
practi≈øe them for their own u≈øe. None but Publick Buildings as are the Temples, Baths, Ho≈øpitals, Coravan≈øerats, Ba≈øarts and Be≈øe≈øtins, that have any thing in any wi≈øe pa≈ø≈øable well contrived. Neverthele≈øs the roofs of many of their Private Hou≈øes are curiou≈øly fieled with inlaid Wood adorned with Gold and Azure to an exce≈ø≈øive co≈øtline≈øs, the upper end of the Room being a little rai≈øed, is covered with Turky Carpets, whereon when they tread they put off their Slip-≈øhoes. In the heat of the day they ≈øit on great out-Windows which many of them have made for that purpo≈øe. But as for Hangings or the like to their Rooms they have none, all their Furniture on the In≈øide being only bare White Walls, unle≈øs ≈øome peculiar Room in the Hou≈øes of tho≈øe of the Highe≈øt Quality.

Their Publick Buildings are va≈øt, and ≈øtately afar off being wonderfully beautifyed by the abundance of Trees planted among the Hou≈øes, ≈øo as each City ≈øeems rather a Wood than a City; which, be≈øide the plea≈øant A≈øpect, ≈øhelters again≈øt the Summer Sun and Winters Wind; the Streets are not broad, but paved with a high foot-Cau≈øay on each ≈øide, in the middle a pa≈ø≈øage for Carts and Hor≈øes; from the Caves on both ≈øides is made a Boarded Arch not very clo≈øe, yet

Turky is furni≈øhed with magnificent Bridges, as Hanes, Mesketoes, High-ways and other publick Structures; and by this means, when any Provincial Governour is both for Riches and Rapin notorious, he is ≈øure ere long to be circumvented, or el≈øe laid open to the Accu≈øer for confiscation, he to prevent this hath no fairer way, than for the publick good to make ≈øome work of eminent magnificence; wherein lie the two ≈øafe points of Reputation, in being held pious and exhau≈øt, the one ≈øtops the Accu≈øer, the other the Exchequer.

But as I have ≈øpoke ≈øomething of their Diet and their Habitations, it will not be impertinent to enlarge a little farther upon their Hou≈øe-keepings and Habitations; the Turks find the advantage of their ≈øparing humour both in War and at home, the greate≈øt Provi≈øions that are carryed into their Camp being only of Rice, potted Butter, and ≈øome dry or poudred Meats, they do not bu≈øy a va≈øt number of Men to ≈øearch after and procure a hundred ≈øorts of different Meats, nor oblige their Souldiers to wander from their main Body to fetch away to the peril of their lives wherewith to ≈øatisfy their Intemperance. And as for their Hou≈øe keeping a Barrel of Rice a year, with ≈øome Pots of Butter, and
dryed Fruits, make the greate≈øt Provi≈øions of a very numerous Family. For my part I can refer to no other Cau≈øe than this the ≈øobriety the ≈øtrength and plumpne≈øs of all the Ea≈øtern-People: And if they were allowed to have great E≈øtates in Property for the receiving of Annual Rents, this Retrenchment and Moderation they have ≈øo long made in their Diet, would have ≈øetled more Rich Families in Con≈øtantinople, than Fea≈øting and Luxury have ruined in all his Maje≈øties three Kingdomes. For a Kitchin in a Hou≈øe is like the Spleen in the Body, the more it Augments, the more the other Faculties dimini≈øh. Neverthele≈øs their Pillaw, Doulma, Boureck, Chorbes and other Dainties would be plea≈øing enough to ≈øome of our nice≈øt Palats in Europe, and whereon a Man might make both a ≈øub≈øtantiall and a delicious meal.

Their Attendants at the Table are Slaves, ≈øuch as have been be≈øtowed upon them by way of Pre≈øent, or which they have obtained in War or by their Money; and the greater number a Man has, the richer he is accounted: They make three Meals a day. But at a Fea≈øt they be≈øiege the Table all the day long, unle≈øs they ri≈øe to ea≈øe Nature and forthwith return. They abominate Hogs-Fle≈øh, Blood, and whatever hath dyed of
it ≈øelf, unle≈øs in extream nece≈ø≈øity. As Wine is prohibited them by their Alcoran, (wherein neverthele≈øs they will debauch to a high Degree in private) their u≈øual Drink is pure Water and ≈øundry ≈øorts of Sherbets, ≈øome made of Sugar and Lemmons, ≈øome of Violets, Peaches, Apricocks, or other Flowers, Fruits or Plumbs, as is the product of each Province; the≈øe are dryed together into a con≈øi≈øtence rea≈øonable hard, and portable for their u≈øe in War, or el≈øewhere, mingling about a ≈øpoonful with a Quart of Water. But one of their mo≈øt common Drinks, now in great reque≈øt with us, is their Coffee, and Coffee-Hou≈øes abound in Turky more than Taverns nay Inns or Ale-Hou≈øes in England. In their Coffee-Hou≈øes upon Scaffolds half a yard High, which they call Sofats, covered with Mats, they ≈øit cro≈øs-leg'd after the Turki≈øh manner, commonly two or three hundred together chatting, often having ≈øome ≈øorry Mu≈øick, thrumming up and down the Room all the while. They are incredible takers of Opium, which abounds in ≈øome of their Provinces, this they ≈øay expelleth all fear and renders them Couragious, but rather wild-headed, and occa≈øioning turbulent Dreams. The Turks are exce≈ø≈øive in their jealou≈øy, ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing therein all other Nations
which is to be a≈øcribed to Polygamy, which renders the Husband unfit for ≈øufficient corre≈øpondence, and ≈øu≈øpicious the Women will ≈øeek for due Benevolence el≈øewhere. Now they are generally exhorted to Matrimony for the propagating of their Law, and the Man lo≈øes his Reputation who deferreth marrying till the Age of five and twenty. Every Man is allowed four Wives, who mu≈øt all pin their Faith upon Mahomets Sleeves, and as many Concubines as he can keep, and that two of any Religion ≈øoever. Yet this ≈øet number of their Wives is no point of their Religion, but a re≈øtriction introduced upon ≈øome Politick Con≈øideration, as too great a Burden and debilitation to mens E≈øtates and Bodies. A Man being bound to make each Wife a Cabin or Dowry, and each by the Law is allowed to claim her ≈øhare in the conjugal allowance, at lea≈øt one night in the Week; for if any of them hath been neglected for a whole Week before, ≈øhe may challenge Thur≈øday night as her due, and the Law hath provided her Remedy in that ca≈øe again≈øt her Husband: But if her mode≈øty will not allow her to ≈øue for one Weeks Default, ≈øhe has neverthele≈øs the Ingenuity to contrive a ≈øupply of her wants. Now as the Women in Turky are kept in the highe≈øt re≈øtraint imaginable, not being
allowed to ≈øtir abroad but muffled all but the Eyes, nor ≈øuffered to go to Church, or look out of the Windows of their own Hou≈øes, nay not to conver≈øe with their own Sons after ≈øuch an Age; ≈øo none in the World can match them in their Ingenious contrivances for the ≈øatisfying their la≈øcivious De≈øires, which are nouri≈øht and fomented to that Degree by the ≈øtrictne≈øs of their Guardians, that the Turki≈øh Women are accounted the mo≈øt immode≈øt Women in the World. Neverthele≈øs, a Wives incontinency does not here redound to the Di≈øgrace and Scandal of a Husband, the Brow-Antlets being placed to the account of the Father, Brother or kindred of the Woman: Her Blood and Family being thereby tainted and di≈øhonoured, and he by a Divorce both rids him≈øelf of his Wife, and purges him≈øelf of the di≈øgrace. But before we ≈øpeak of the formalities of a Divorce, it will not be impertinent to ≈ø ‚Ä¢ t down tho≈øe of a Wedding. Now having bought their Wife of her Parents, and recorded the contract before the Cadi they ≈øolemnize their marriage in this manner. Many Women are invited by the Mother of the Bride to accompany her the night before the Marriage day, whereof they ≈øpend a great part in fea≈øting; then lead they her
into a Bath, where they anoint and bath her. So breaking company, they depart unto their ≈øeveral Re≈øts, and in the morning return unto her Chamber; where they deck her in her riche≈øt Ornaments, tying on her Silcken Buskins with Knots not ea≈øily unknit. The Bridegroom having fea≈øted a number in like manner, in the morning they al≈øo repair to his Hou≈øe in their be≈øt Trappings, and nobly mounted, from whence they ≈øet forward two and two in a Rank, to fetch home the Bride, accompanyed with Mu≈øick, and conducted by the Sagdich, who is the neare≈øt of his Kindred. To the Sagdich the Bride is delivered with her Face clo≈øe covered, and then ≈øhe is ≈øet a≈øtride on Hor≈øe-back, with a Canopy carryed over her in ≈øuch manner, as no part of her is to be di≈øcerned. Thus does this Troup return in the ≈øame order that it came, having their Pre≈øents and Apparel carryed after them in Serbets or a kind of Baskets, and then follows the Bride her ≈øelf, and la≈øt of all her Slaves if any have been given her. The Bridegroom ≈øtandeth at his Door to receive her, and has all re≈øpects paid him by his Gue≈øts: who neverthele≈øs go not in, and is regated by them with ≈øeveral Pre≈øents before their departure. If ≈øhe be of Quality, ≈øhe is led to the Bride Chamber by an Eunuch,
where Women ≈øtand prepared to undre≈øs her. But the Bridegroom him≈øelf mu≈øt untie her Buskins, to which he is fain to apply his Teeth. Now he mu≈øt entertain his Wifes with equal re≈øpect, giving them the ≈øame Diet, the ≈øame Apparel, and the ≈øame Benevolence, being expre≈øsly ordained in the precepts of their Doctors, and all this mu≈øt be exactly ob≈øerved unle≈øs they are willing, and con≈øent to change Turns, and upon Default they may procure a Divorce upon complaint to the Cadi: Now they have three Degrees of Divorce, every one of which is made, before the Cadi, and by him both extracted and Regi≈øtred; the fir≈øt ≈øeparates the Man and Wife only from the ≈øame Hou≈øe and Bed, the Wife being ≈øtill allowed her Maintenance; the ≈øecond divides them not only in that manner, but the Husband is compelled to make good her Kabin, or Dowry promi≈øed at her Marriage, ≈øo as to have no Intere≈øt either in him or his E≈øtate, and to be at perfect Freedome to Marry another, the third ≈øort of Divorce is called (Ouch Talac) and is made in a Solemn and more Serious manner, with more rigorous terms of ≈øeparation, and in this ca≈øe the Husband repenting of his Divorce, and de≈øirous to take his Wife again, cannot be admitted to her by
the Law, without con≈øenting and contenting him≈øelf to ≈øee an other Man enjoy her before his Face, an injunction ordained by the Law for a puni≈øhment of the Husbands levity and incon≈øtancy. And how ≈øevere a Condition ≈øoever this may ≈øeem, there be ≈øome Turks who are content to accept of them again upon tho≈øe Articles, and make choice of ≈øome hand≈øome Youth for the entring their Wifes Bed. In ≈øome ca≈øes a Woman with many of her Friends goes before a Cadi, where weeping and taking off her Shoe, ≈øhe holds the Soal upwards but ≈øays nothing, and this ceremony is u≈øed when a marryed Woman complains that her Husband would abu≈øe her again≈øt Nature. And no delivery can be ≈øo clean and neat as this by way of Emblem, ≈øuch Facts being too unclean for Language; there are ≈øome other points pleadable in Law for Divorce in behalf of the Woman, as impotency or frigidity in the Husband, and the like; as al≈øo if he maintain her not with Bread, Butter, Rice, and Flax to Spin for her cloathing, the Law ≈øuppo≈øing her ≈øo good a Hu≈øwife as to ≈øupply her ≈øelf with her own Labour; they have al≈øo a ≈øort of half Marriage among them which is called Kabin, when a man takes a Wife for a Month, or for a certain limited time, and an agreement
is made for the price before the Cadee or Judge: and this is chiefly u≈øed by Strangers. Moreover there is ≈øtill an other ≈øort of Marriages practi≈øed in Turky, which is the Conjunction of an Eunuch with a Woman; ≈øuch as are wholly deprived and di≈øarmed of all parts of Manhood, and yet do notwith≈øtanding take many Wives, and exerci≈øe Lu≈øts of an unknown and prodigious Nature.

One Priviledge the Grand Seigniors Subjects, have more then their Soveraign, that they can marry whom they plea≈øe, whereas he can marry none at all, under which re≈øtriction tho≈øe Princes have lain ever ≈øince the misfortune of Bajazet, who being a Pri≈øoner to Tamerlane had his dearly beloved Wife De≈øpina violated before his very Eyes; In≈øomuch that the Sultans to prevent ≈øuch like Misfortunes and Di≈øhonours for the future, take no Female companion of their Empire, in whom they can intere≈øs them≈øelves farther than as Slaves, or for the lo≈øs of Goods, Riches or E≈øtates. Be≈øides this Policy has a larger extent, for it puts off all tho≈øe va≈øt Dowries, which otherwi≈øe ≈øhould be made an≈øwerable to a Sultana's Condition, ≈øo that by this means a great part of the Revenues of the Empire would be diverted from the true Channel of its Intere≈øt
and Con≈øervation, and lavi≈øht upon u≈øes rather tending to its Undermining and Debilitation, than to the ≈øetling and augmenting its Grandeur.

The Children the Turks have by their Slaves, are equally e≈øteemed by them with tho≈øe they have by their Wives, bating this difference in e≈øteem of the Law, that unle≈øs the Father manumi≈ø≈øes them by his Te≈øtament, and conferrs a lively-hood upon them by Legacy, they remain to the Charity of the Elder Brother that is born from the Wife, and are his Slaves, and he their Lord and Ma≈øter, ≈øo that from the Loins of the ≈øame Father may proceed Children of a ≈øervile and ignominious Condition. The Women re≈øpect their Hu ‚Ä¢ band as a Ma≈øter; receive cha≈øtizement from him, which they interpret as a mark of his Affection, they eat apart, unle≈øs particularly called by the Husband, and do not concern them≈øelves with Dome≈øtick Affairs, the Principal of their bu≈øine≈øs being to ≈øtudy all the ways po≈ø≈øible to plea≈øe their Husband, Nur≈øe their own Children, and cultivate their Charms. And indeed they are generally well featured, clear, ≈ømooth, and ruddy complexioned, with large black Eyes, which they con≈øider as a Beauty, and is to be one of the greate≈øt Charms of Mahomets Paradice, and
tho≈øe who have not naturally black Eyes, have the Art to make them ≈øeem ≈øo, and al≈øo dye their Eye La≈øhes and Eye brows, as they al≈øo do the hair of their Head which they wear ≈øometimes di≈øhevell'd. Their Nails they paint with a Yellowi≈øh Red. On the top of their Heads they wear a Cap not unlike the top of a Sugar-loaf, yet a little flat of Pa≈øte-Board, and covered with Cloth of Silver or Ti≈ø≈øue.

Women of the better Rank wear about the upper parts of their Armes, and ≈ømalls of their Leggs, Bracelets, and are el≈øewhere adorned with Jewels. When they go abroad they wear over all long Gowns of Violet or Scarlet Cloth, tyed clo≈øe before, the large Sleeves hanging over their Hands, having Buskins on their Leggs, and their Heads and Faces ≈øo mufled in fine Linnen that no more is to be ≈øeen of them than their Eyes, nor that of ≈øome, who look as through a Bevour, being forbidden by their Alchoran to di≈øclo≈øe their Beautyes unto any ≈øave their Fathers and their Husbands.

The next that fall in our way to ≈øpeak of after their Wives, be their Slaves, who are Chri≈øtians taken in War or purcha≈øed with their Money. Of tho≈øe there are weekly Markets in each City, where they are to be ≈øold as Hor≈øes in Fairs, the Men
being prized according to their faculties or Per≈øonal abilities, and the Women for their Youths and Beauties, being decked with all the Ornaments that can in≈øpire Love and Affection, and allure and invite Chapmen. And as Jockyes view and examine every Part and Limb before they ≈øtrike up a Bargain, ≈øo are they ≈øo ≈øcrutinous as to ≈øearch even her very Mouth. Their Ma≈øters may lye with them, cha≈øti≈øe them, exchange and ≈øell them at their Plea≈øure: If any Slave become a Mahometan, he is di≈øcharged his Bondage. The old and the mo≈øt deformed are put to the mo≈øt Drudgery, the Men-Slaves may compel their Ma≈øters before the Cady, to limit the time of their Bondage, or ≈øet a price of their Redemption, or el≈øe to ≈øell them unto an other; but whether of the two, they lightly refer unto the Slaves Election. If they be only fit for Labour, they will accept of the Time, but if skillful in any craft, of the Price, which expired or paid, they may return unto their Countryes. But Gally-Slaves are ≈øeldom relea≈øed, in regard of their ≈ømall number, and much employment which they have for them: Nor tho≈øe that are Slaves unto great ones, to whom the Cady's Authority extends not.

Many of the Children that the Turks do buy, they ca≈øtrate, making all ≈ømooth as the back of the Hand, whereof divers do dye in cutting, who ≈øupply the u≈øes of Nature with a Silver Quill, which they wear in their Turbants. In times pa≈øt, they only did but geld them; but being admitted to the free Conver≈øe of their Women, it was ob≈øerved by ≈øome that they more than ordinarily delighted in their Societies. But others, that one of the Sultans ≈øeeing a Gelding cover a Mare, brought in among them that Inhumane Cu≈øtome. Eunuchs are in great repute with their Ma≈øters in Turky, being intru≈øted with the whole management of their E≈øtates, the Government of their Women and Hou≈øes in their ab≈øence, and have ≈øhown them≈øelves ≈øo Tru≈øty, Loyal, Prudent and Couragious, that they have often been called to the Helm, and had the whole conduct of the State committed to their Care.

As for the Trade, and Sciences of the Turks, ≈øome of them have ≈øome ≈ømall In≈øight and Knowledge in Philo≈øophy. Phy≈øick they have learnt rather from nece≈ø≈øity and experience than the Grounds of the Art. A≈øtronomy is in great vogue with them, and there be many pretenders to it, who ≈øit frequently in the Streets of the City
to tell Fortunes, and are re≈øorted to by ≈øuch as are to go a Journey or undertake any affair of Moment. They have a knack in Poetry, wherein they chaunt their Amours in the Per≈øian Tongue to vile Mu≈øick, yet are they forbidden ≈øo to do by their Law; Citterns, Harps, and Recorders being their Principal In≈øtruments. But their loud In≈øtruments do rather terrify than plea≈øe, and charm the Ear. They neither ≈øtudy, nor are farther acquainted with Rhetorick or Logick than what meer Nature does afford. Hi≈øtorians they have, tho' their Writings read by none or few, as fancying none can give us the truth of the time pa≈øt, ≈øince none dare write the Truth of what is pre≈øent. Nor indeed is Printing tolerated in Turky, for the Grand Seignior having ob≈øerved Learning and the Pre≈øs to have been the chief fomenters of Divi≈øions in Chri≈øtendome, has prohibited them his Dominions, and makes his Subjects contented with ≈øuch learning as proceeds from le≈øs erring Experience, which they find adapt them ≈øufficiently for all State-employments, and ≈øooner furni≈øhes them with clearer rea≈øon, than tho≈øe who run through a long cour≈øe of canting Terms, ≈øtrang Languages and mu≈øty Arts, which the Cu≈øtome of their Univer≈øities does oblige their Students to. And indeed
their Mini≈øtry has been found ≈øo expert, ≈øo Prudent and ≈øo ≈øagacious in all their Negociations and Tran≈øactions, that they could never be over-reached by the mo≈øt learned and mo≈øt Politick Princes of Chri≈øtendom. Thus all Sciences that have any affinity to tho≈øe we call liberal, are taught no where ≈øave in the Seraglio, as we ≈øhall ≈øhew more at large hereafter, where the Grand Seignior hath power to increa≈øe or dimini≈øh the number of their Profe≈ø≈øours according as it ≈øuits his Occa≈øions. By which conduct tho≈øe many Schi≈øms and Di≈øtractions which in the State of mo≈øt Chri≈øtian Princes do frequently happen both in Church and State, are foreclo≈øed and prevented, and tho≈øe many refined Mercurial Heads, which with us for want of employment make it their Bu≈øine≈øs to blow up the flames of Sedition, are ≈øeta ‚Ä¢ nd bred to more gro≈øs Employments, and become more eager and intent upon Profit and ≈øen≈øual Plea≈øures, than the vain and often de≈øolating De≈øtructive Projects of our ≈øpeculative Men. Writing they u≈øe, and that in the Arabick Characters, but leave out the Vowels unle≈øs it be at the end of a word, ≈øo that much is contained in a little Room; they curiou≈øly ≈øleek their Paper which is thick, much of it being Coloured and dappelled like Chamblets, done by a
trick they have of dipping it in Water. Every one hath ≈øome Trade or other, not ≈øo much as the Grand Seignior excepted. Yet their Trades are ≈øuch as ≈øerve only their own U≈øes and Nece≈ø≈øities, and not ≈øuch as ≈øupply forreign Marts, which they do not much frequent. And tho' the Turks be exce≈ø≈øively avaricious, yet they only work by ≈øtarts, and more for their Amu≈øement and Recreation then for Profit. The Europeans have taught them to be ≈øubtle, nay treacherous in their compacts and dealings, tho' indeed it mu≈øt be owned, they have not yet attained to the skill of their Ma≈øters. There is no People more covetous of Salutation than the Turks, in meeting upon the High-way one with a ≈øtoop, and his Hand upon his Brea≈øt, bids Salaum Aleek, the other with like abey≈øance, replyes Aleek Salaum: And when any one comes into Company, the re≈øt ≈øalute him with a Merrabbak Sultanum, ever ≈øweetning their Conver≈øation, with ≈øuch accent of Pronunciation, and ≈øo much re≈øpective ge≈øture, as ≈øavours of a gentle Genius, free from that rudene≈øs whereof they are accu≈øed.

After their departure this Life, the Men by the Men, and the Women by the Women are laid out in the middle of the Room. Whereupon diver≈øe of their Prie≈øts do a≈ø≈øemble
about the Body, and having performed certain vain Ceremonies, as in wrapping their Beads about it, and in the often turning it, invoking God to have mercy on the departed, they wa≈øh it, ≈øhave it, and ≈øhrowd it in Linnen, which they leave untyed both at hands and Feet. Then lay the Coar≈øe on a Beer, placing a Turbant at the upper end, and carry it to the Grave, with the Head forward: ≈øome of the Dervi≈øes going before with Tapers, the Prie≈øt ≈øinging after, and la≈øtly his Friends and Acquaintance. But Per≈øons of Principal Quality have their Hor≈øes led before them, with en≈øignes trailed on the Earth, and other Rites of that Nature, divers of the Lanters going before, naming of God, and ≈øhaking of their Heads, and whirling about until they fall down giddy, the ≈øides and bottomes of the Grave are Boarded. For they are of opinion that two terrible Angels called Mongi ‚Ä¢
and Gudequir, do pre≈øently repair unto the Grave, and put the Soul again into the Body, as if (≈øaith the Alcoran) a Man ≈øhould put on his Shirt and rai≈øing him on his Knees, with his Head uncovered, (the winding Sheet being left unknit for that purpo≈øe) demand of him in particular how he hath behaved him≈øelf in this Life. Which if not well, the one ≈øtrikes him on the Head
with a Hammer nine fathome into the Earth, the other tearing him with an Iron Hook; and ≈øo continue to torment until the day of Judgment. A Purgatory ≈øo feared, that in their prayers they Petition God to deliver them from the Examinations of the Black Angels, the tortures of the Grave and their evil Journey. But if he have ≈øatisfyed them in this reply, they vani≈øh away, and two white Angels come in their Places, the one laying his Arm under his Head, the other ≈øitting at his Feet, and ≈øo Protect him until Dooms day. Their Sepultures are notable; tho≈øe of Princes or great Men, are covered over with Silk, or Cloth of Gold, with a Turbant at the Head, land ≈øet under a vaulted Arch ≈øupported by four Marble Pillars; ≈øome with a little Cock of Fountain Water, and Lamps continually burning; they are made near the Mo≈øquees, e≈øpecially if they built one, but never with in them; the more ordinary are buryed in ≈øome plea≈øant Place without the City, with a high Stone ≈øtanding at the Head, and another at the Feet; that at the Head, hath ≈øometimes an Epitaph, and if it be a Man of Quality, is made at top in form of a Turbant; tho≈øe who be≈øtow a Marble Stone over them, have it in the middle cut through about a yard long, and
a Foot broad; therein they Plant ≈øuch a kind of Plants, or Flowers as endure Green all the Year long; which ≈øeem to grow out of the dead Body, thinking thereby to reduce it again into Play, tho' not in the Scene of ≈øen≈øible Creatures, yet of tho≈øe vegitable, which is the next degree, and perhaps a preferment beyond the Du≈øt. The Women flock every Thur≈øday in Multitudes to the Graves, weeping over their Children, Husbands, Kinsfolks and dead Progenitors, often ki≈ø≈øing the Stones, and praying for their delivery from the afore≈øaid Black tortures; many times leaving Bread and Meat on the Graves for Dogs and Birds to devour, as well as to relieve the Poor, being held an available Alms for the decea≈øed. The better ≈øort do mourn in white, and but for a little ≈øea≈øon. And the Women are not to marry by their Law, until four Months and ten days after their Husbands death.

But tho' their Doctours do differ very much in the Explication of the Law, yet a Man ≈øhall be accounted a Mu≈ø≈øulman or true Believer, it he ob≈øerve the≈øe five Articles or Fundamentals of the Law, to which every Turk is bound.

Now for the more ea≈øy obtruding this ‚Ä¢ ew Contrivance upon the World, Mahomet decked it with ≈øuch Ornaments of ‚Ä¢ he Jewi≈øh and Chri≈øtian Religion, as he fancyed would mo≈øt take the Eye and ‚Ä¢ rocure him Votaries out of the Pale of their Churches, yet leaving out ≈øuch ≈øolemni

div.p:
This Mufti created as is before ≈øaid by the Emperour, to whom he is held ever ≈øubordinate; which makes the Turki≈øh Theology excellently to corre≈øpond with the State, as depending thereon: and ≈øeems of rea≈øon more Politick, then if this Head Eccle≈øia≈øtick were of another Country, or otherwi≈øe independant upon the Prince, whereby having ≈øeparate Intere≈øts, he might often make God Almighty ≈øeem to decree more conform thereto, than either to the occa≈øions of the Prince or common Wealth; for all the Heatheni≈øh Gods, are u≈øed like Puppets, they ≈øeem to ≈øpeak, yet it is not they, but the Man who in a concealed manner, ≈øpeaks through them what he plea≈øes. For tho' the ≈øupream Head of judicature is the Mufti's, there being no appeal beyond him in the greate≈øt ca≈øe ≈øoever, nor the Emperour him≈øelf que≈øtioning his Decrees, and the rea≈øon is becau≈øe they are ≈øecretly guided by his a≈ø≈øent and the Grand Viziors. Thus the Mufti is an In≈øtrument made u≈øe of to Spirit the Souldiers by colouring of publick Projects, and re≈øolves by Divine
Authority, and al≈øo to de≈øide contraver≈øies, when they are too unruly, for any arbitrement not held Divine. Neverthele≈øs, as I ≈øaid, underhand he con≈øults the Grand Viziers, who lets him know the Grand Seigniors Mind, and being thus in≈øpired with that Soul, full of that God, he utters his Orracles; which pa≈øs for the Word of God, as con≈øidering them grounded upon the Alcoran.

This cour≈øe has been ≈øtrictly ob≈øerved by the Ottoman Policy, well knowing that the Keys of the Church can hang no where ≈øo quietly as at the Princes Girdle, and con≈øidering that by this means the Court provided it ≈øelf with a favourable Empire, and who ≈øeemed of a more ≈øanctifyed and indifferent allay, than a ≈øecular Mini≈øter, and both by receiving from, and adding a greater lu≈øtre to the Beames of Religion, would be the more acceptable arbitrator for the compo≈øing any di≈øcontents, that might be fomented between the civil Power and the Subject, either through others Ambition or their own Oppre≈ø≈øion, not unlikely to re≈øult from ≈øo ab≈øolute a Juri≈ødiction. The Mufti ≈øeldome appears in Publick, ≈øo that the People have him in that Veneration, as if they con≈øidered ≈øomething about him more then Humane. He is cloathed in
Green, which kind none but the Kindred of Mahomet are ≈øuffered to wear. N ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Malefactour is ≈øuffered to dye, who hat ‚Ä¢ the Fortune to ≈øee or be ≈øeen by him as h ‚Ä¢ pa≈ø≈øeth. But notwith≈øtanding the Princ ‚Ä¢ Places him upon all weighty Occa≈øions nex ‚Ä¢ to the Throne, and be≈øtows and ≈øuffer ‚Ä¢ him to receive all the other Honours in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ginable, yet if he is in the lea≈øt found inclinable to run-counter to the Will and de≈øigns of the Court, he is ≈øtraity removed It having been a Maxime long ob≈øerved i ‚Ä¢ this Empire, that neither Friends, Money Sanctity, Love of People, former de≈øerts or any pre≈øent need of the Per≈øons accurate Parts, ≈øhould in any wi≈øe bya≈øs the practi≈øed Method of this Government, o ‚Ä¢ removing upon the lea≈øt umbrage and jealou≈øy ≈øoever given to the Grand Seignior, by any Mini≈øter or other Per≈øon, the Prince e≈øteeming no number of Lives, tho' never ≈øo Innocent, equivalent with his ≈øafety, and the Nations. But tho' this Holy Man comes to an unnatural Death. the Honour of his Place is ≈øo far from receiving any Blemi≈øh by it, that his Body goes to the Grave without any A≈øper≈øion, and his Succe≈ø≈øour Mounts his Chair without any prejudice, far from being bla≈øted with tho≈øe errours that have been fa≈øtened upon Popes
and Patriarchs by their Predece≈ø≈øours ill ‚Ä¢ onduct. For here the Mufti how≈øoever ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ l he had de≈øerved of Church or State is ‚Ä¢ egi≈øtred among≈øt their Saints. And herein ‚Ä¢ ppears a main point of the Turki≈øh Policy, ‚Ä¢ or by the≈øe means they prevent the truth of his Judgment being brought into Que
‚Ä¢ tion while he is in being, which no Man will do of a Per≈øon who≈øe Actions he dares not arraign after he is Dead.

But we have con≈øidered this Divine Man ≈øufficiently, it is now fit that we look a while into the Alcoran, which Book the Turks never touch with unwa≈øhed Hands; and a Capital Crime it is in the reading thereof to mi≈øtake a Letter, or di≈øplace the accent, they ki≈øs it, embrace it, and ≈øwear by it: calling it the Book of Glory and directour unto Paradice. It teaches that God is only to be wor≈øhipped, only one and the Creatour of all Righteous, pitiful: In Wi≈ødom and power Incomprehen≈øible. How God made Man of all ≈øorts and Colours of Earth; and being formed for thou≈øands of Years laid him a Baking in the Sun, until he was plea≈øed to breath Life into him. Then commanded he all his Angels, to reverence him: which the Devil at that time, an Angel of Light, refu≈øed to do, expo≈øtulating why he ≈øhould ≈øo honour that
Creature whom he knew would becom ‚Ä¢ ≈øo polluted with all manner of Vices, tha ‚Ä¢ God therefore condemned the Devil to Hell who ever ≈øince hath continued an Enem ‚Ä¢ to Man. Idolatry they hold to be the mo≈ø ‚Ä¢ accur≈øed of Crimes, and therefore they interdict all Images and Counterfeits ≈øoever reputing the Chri≈øtians Idolaters for that they have them in their Churches and Hou≈øes. But there was al≈øo a Politick motive of this Prohibition of Maohmets, who con≈øidered that it was impo≈ø≈øible if a Nation once attains an Univer≈øal Prudence, but that the deceitful knack of ≈øuch a Carnal Adoration mu≈øt needs grow loath≈øome, or lye obvious to their reproof, that ≈øhall make it their full employment to find faults; and after an opportunity is ea≈øily gained, to foment a Change, by di≈øcovering to the People ab≈øurdities in their Wor≈øhip; which is better prevented, in one directed as his is, to the only Invi≈øible and Omnipotent Creatour, who≈øe Nature and Power is ≈øo far remote from the weake apprehen≈øions of Men, as the ≈øharpe≈øt Rea≈øon is not able to batter a Faith ≈øolely built upon it. They are commanded ≈øeaven times a day to re≈øort unto Publick Prayers: the fir≈øt a≈ø≈øembling is called Singilnamas, which is two Hours before day; the ≈øecond Sabahnamas, at day
break; the third Vyle-namas at noon; the fourth Kyndinameus at three of the Clock: the fifth Ak≈øhamnamas after Sun ≈øet: the ≈øixth Chogicnamas, two Hours within night: and the ≈øeventh Giuma-namas at ten of the Clock in the Night: the two la≈øt al≈øo on Fridayes ob≈øerved by all, on the other days but by the more Religious: congregated they are by the chanting of Prie≈øts from the tops of Steeples; at which times lightly tho' they be in the Fields; they will ≈øpread the upper Garments on the Earth, and fall to their Devotions. Friday is their Sabbath, yet they ≈øpend but a part thereof in Devotion, the re≈øt in Recreations; but for that time they ob≈øerve it ≈øo rigorou≈øly that all Per≈øons are exemplarily puni≈øhed that tran≈øgre≈øs the orders of it. Before they pray they wa≈øh all the Organs of their ≈øences; their Legs to their Knees, and their Arms to their Elbows: their Privities after their purging of Nature; and ≈øometimes all over from top to toe: for which there are Hou≈øes of Office with Conduits belonging to every Principal Mo≈øque. Where Water is wanting they do it with Du≈øt. At the Door of the Mo≈øque, they put of their Shoes, and entring ≈øit cro≈øs legg'd upon rows of Mats one behind another, the Poor and the Rich promi≈øcuou≈øly, the Prie≈øt in
a Pulpit before them, not otherwi≈øe di≈øtingui≈øhed in Habit, but by the folding of their Turbant. When they pray they turn their Faces toward Mecca: fir≈øt ≈øtanding upright; without any Motions of their Bodies, holding the Palms of their Hands upward; ≈øometimes they ≈øtop their Eyes and Ears, and oft pull their Heir on the ≈øides of their Faces; then thrice they Bow, as in their Salutations; and as often pro≈øterating them≈øelves on the Earth. Doing this ≈øundry times they will look back upon no Occa≈øion, until they come unto the Salutation of Mahomet: at which time they rever≈øe their Faces, fir≈øt over the Right Shoulder, and then over the left, believing that his coming will be behind them, when they are at their Devotion, the Prie≈øt doth ≈øometimes read unto them ≈øome part of the Alcoran. This Book is written in Arabick Ver≈øe, in forme of a Dialogue, between the Angel Gabriel and their Prophet, it is prohibited to be tran≈ølated, which both pre≈øerves the Arabick Tongue, and conceals Religion. All ≈øet Texts are obnoxious to ≈øeveral Expo≈øitions, thence grows Di≈øtractions ≈øo hath this Bread four different Sects of Mahometans, each interpreting it according to the Genius of its Nation, the Tartars ≈øimply, the Moors and Arabs ≈øupe≈øtitiou≈øly;
the Per≈øian Ingeniou≈øly, the Turks with mo≈øt liberty, each nation ≈øcornes to yield to other in opinion, for honour ≈øake, e≈øpecially the Turk and Per≈øian, who nowri≈øhing De≈øigns of Conque≈øt of each other, do after the Old Cu≈øtome of Princes, di≈øaffect their People in Religion toward the Enemy that they may be more fierce and ob≈øtinate again≈øt him.

A great means as I have already ≈øaid, of Mohometi≈ømes making that Progre≈øs in the World, is its plea≈øing Doctrine, ≈øuited to the depraved Inclinations of Mankind, it being ≈øaid in the Alcoran that when their Prophet asked the Angel concerning Venery and ≈øome other delicacyes of life, he told him; that God did not give Man ≈øuch Appetites, to have them fru≈øtrate but enjoyed, as made for the Gu≈øt of Man, not his torment, wherein his Creatour delights not, upon this it is, and for the drawing in Luxurious Complexions, which perhaps are the greate≈øt part of Mankind, that the Alcoran permits Poligamy to make a numerous People, which is the Foundation of all great Empires; and prohibits Wine, pretending a Devil in every Grape; thereby hardening the Souldier, preventing di≈øorder, and facillitating publick Provi≈øion. The fir≈øt being grateful to Nature is generally
received but the other is overpowred by Appetite, ≈øo that many more Drink than ab≈øtain from Wine. Two other Principal points I ≈øhall touch upon in the Mahometan Religion. One is Prede≈øtination, the other Purgatory: the fir≈øt not meant in matter of Salvation, but of Fortune, and ≈øucce≈øs in this Life, they peremptoryly permit to De≈øtiny fixt, and not avoydable by any Act of ours. And yet this opinion of fate which u≈øually takes Men off from all Indu≈øtrious Care of their own ≈øafety, does not ≈øl ‚Ä¢ cker their Diligence in dangers at Sea, and other ca≈øes. They admit no Hell for any but tho≈øe who believe not Mahomet; their own they afright with a Purgatory, which holds but tell Doomes day; it is acted in the Grave, the pain is inflicted by a bad Angel, who≈øe force is le≈ø≈øoned by a good one, according as the partyes Life was led. To ≈øtrengthen this good Angel, they do many Works of Charity, erecting Hanes, Ho≈øpitals and Mesketoes, making Bridges and High ways, and ≈øtoring them with Fountains and other Conveniencyes for the relief of Travellers.

Having ≈øpoke ≈øo much of the Religion it ≈øelf, it is now convenient to ≈øay ≈øomething of the manner of its Exerci≈øe, which is this in ≈øhort; every Mo≈øque has a high ≈ølender
Spyre Steeple adjoyning: on the out≈øide whereof and high, is made abound or Tower with a Door opening South-Ea≈øt or Ea≈øt, as the Countrye lyes towards Meccha; here the Prie≈øt or Muazzin entring, with his Hands bowed over his Ears walking round, turning on the Right Hand, in a loud voice tells the People, many times over that there is but one God, which having performed, all tho≈øe that are piou≈øly given, throng to the Mo≈øque, and ≈øay their Prayers, continually repeating Allah heeber, as al≈øo the profe≈ø≈øion of their Faith, and then they ≈øay Ahia Elfela, Ahia Elfela, which ≈øignifies come away to prayers, I give you fair notice. Their ge≈øtures are fir≈øt ≈øitting cro≈øs legg'd, wafting of the Body, then pro≈øtrate twice on their Face, they ki≈øs the Earth; afterward they ri≈øe, and ≈øtand with their Hand bowed over their Ears, but never do they kneel or uncover their Head, accounting tho≈øe po≈øtures un≈øeeming. Having already mentioned how often this ≈øervice is performed, It is fitting that I in≈øert, that they believe that the Jews and Chri≈øtians not having obeyed the Command they had received from God, of praying to him often, he ordered Mahomet to pre≈øcribe to the Mu≈ø≈øulmans
that they ≈øhould addre≈øs to him fifty times a day their Vows and Prayers, but he fore≈øeeing that his followers could not well acquit them≈øelves of this Commandment, he prevailed ≈øo far with God that he contented him≈øelf with the tenth part of the Homages, that he meant to have had paid him, and that this great number of fifty prayers a day, was reduced to five, now the la≈øt and fir≈øt Service which is at day break and an Hour after Sun≈øet makes a fine Show, all the Mo≈øques being hung full of burning Lamps; but none are bound to this frequency of prayer, but ≈øuch Per≈øons as have lei≈øure, others making the High-way or their Hou≈øes ≈øerve the turn, and this was devi≈øed to keep Religion from falling into the danger of oblivion, which is in no wi≈øe better maintain'd than by being often called to mind. Their Sabbath is kept on the Friday, tho' not ob≈øerved with all the ≈øtrictne≈øs that Sundays are or ought to be among≈øt us. Moreover they have two ≈øolemn times: Bairam and Ramazan, they are both Lents, the fir≈øt la≈øts three days, the other a month: their Fa≈øt is according to the Jewi≈øh manner, not in quantity or quality of Meats, but in time; for all the day long, they may neither eat, drink, nor u≈øe any ≈øort of venery; but at
the appearance of the fir≈øt Star, thay make reprizals, gorging them≈øelves in all manner of Gluttony and Lu≈øt. Be≈øides the Turks have one piece of Divinity peculiar to them≈øelves, which is a Cu≈øtome of their Prie≈øts to ≈øell their merit; ≈øome more, ≈øome le≈øs, according to the Sanctimony of the Seller. But before I clo≈øe up this Article of Religion, I will ≈øet down what things a Turk is bound to do before prayers, which may be reduced to five. The fir≈øt, is to believe the Articles of the Mahometan Faith. The ≈øecond, to be Circumcized. The third, to pardon ones Enemyes. The fourth, is to call out at the Turret of the Church Steeples, or to go to the Mo≈øque when one is called thither. And the fifth, is to wa≈øh ones ≈øelf, which is the immediate Preparation to prayer. Now all the Articles of the Mahometan Faith may be reduced to two, namely that there is one God, and that Mahomet is his Prophet or me≈ø≈øenger, and that that only God is the Creatour of Heaven and of Earth, and ab≈øolute Ma≈øter of all things. For which rea≈øon they do not ≈øuffer in their Mo≈øques any Image repre≈øenting any living thing, either in relief or meer painting. The ≈øecond Article of the Mahometan Faith comprehends an abridgment of all the mad fancyes and extravagancyes
of the Alcoran and of all its Commentatours, believing that Mahomet is the Me≈ø≈øenger of God, and that there cannot be a more certain truth, than all that this Impo≈øtour has left them either in Writing or Tradition. This Article being the Fountain of all the re≈øt, it is not nece≈ø≈øary that I hear in≈øert all their ≈øilly fancies of the Creation of the World, of its Pre≈øervation, and of the cour≈øe God takes to ≈øanctify and ≈øave it; nor ≈øhall I ≈øpeak of all their whim≈øycal Opinions and ≈øo little conformable to right rea≈øon with which they fill their Minds and ≈øtuff their Books. Enough already has been ≈øaid of their Paradice which they make all Spiritual by the beatifick Vi≈øion of God, and all brutal by a glut of all ≈øen≈øual plea≈øures, and their affording Roome there to ≈øeveral Brute Animals. Nor ≈øhall I ≈øo much as touch upon the Per≈øons whom they admit into the Li≈øt of their Prophets, the number being too great, and who may all be reduced to the≈øe three, Mo≈øes, Je≈øus Chri≈øt. Who≈øe Divine Filiation and Death upon the Cro≈øs they deny, and Mahomet, whom they believe to be the greate≈øt of all. But will fall to give ≈øome account of their Circumci≈øion, and their manner of performing it. Being often hindred by a Phimo≈øis from ≈øatisfying his
Brutalities, had his fore skin cut, and ordered that all his followers ≈øhould cau≈øe them≈øelves to be circumci≈øed, that ≈øo the Bodyes of his Mu≈ø≈øulmans might again be known that were killed in the Battells, they ≈øhould fight for the e≈øtabli≈øhment of his Law, that ≈øo they might be interred and Honoured as Martyres, whether it was for the more drawing in the Jews to follow his errours by the re≈øemblance of that Ceremony, which only differs from theirs in that having cut the fore skin, they do not tear like them, with the Naile a little of the Fle≈øh, which is above what the Anotami≈øts call the Curb, whether in ≈øhort, that this impure Legis lator affecting an exteriour neatne≈øs, for the better hiding from the People the filth of his Mind, he commanded tho≈øe who had already embraced his errours, to have their foreskin cut, becau≈øe that it might otherwi≈øe detain ≈øome ordures, by which means a Mahometan pre≈øenting him≈øelf to prayer, without being entirely purifyed, would not be heard of God. Who would con≈øider him as a Mordar, that is to ≈øay, unbelieving impure and Gullyed.

This Circum≈øicion which the Turks call Shounet, is only a mark of their Obedience to the vocal Words of Mahomet, who has not written it in his Alcoran; but ordered
it only afterwards, ≈øeeing he had many followers to di≈øtingui≈øh them from the Chri≈øtians who have the foreskin; and from the Jews who have it otherwi≈øe cut then they, tho' that their Circumci≈øion be received among the Mahometans.

Tho≈øe whom they Circumci≈øe mu≈øt have attained to the Age of ≈øeven or eight years, never younger, but often much older. The day being appointed for the Ceremony, a Fea≈øt is prepared at the Hou≈øe of the Per≈øon to be circumci≈øed. Who is dre≈ø≈øed as fine as Hands can make him, and having ≈øet him upon a Hor≈øe or Camel, they carry him all about the Town if it is ≈ømall, or only in his own Prince or Pari≈øh if it be great. His Scool-Fellows and Friends follow him all on Foot huzzaing and ≈øhouting the pray≈øes of their Friend, who is going to be li≈øted, in the number of the Mu≈ø≈øulmans or true Believers. The Cavalcade being ended, and the People returned home. The Imam of the Mo≈øque of the Place, makes a ≈øhort Exhortation upon the Operation that is going to be made, then a Chirurgion having placed the Young-man upon the Sofa or State, two Servants hold a Toilet ≈øtrerched out before him, and the Chirurgion having drawn out the Fore-skin
‚Ä¢ s far as he can, he ≈øeizes it with a ≈ømall ‚Ä¢ air of Pincers at the end of the Balances,
‚Ä¢ hen with his Razour cuts it neatly, and ‚Ä¢ howes it round his Finger, which he lifts up crying ≈øeveral times, Alla Hecberia, alla, ‚Ä¢ lla. He then dre≈ø≈øes the circumci≈øed Per≈øon, who gives ≈øufficiently to under≈øtand by his Groans, how much pain a Wound puts him to, made in ≈øo ticling a part, and the by-≈øtanders continuing their acclamations ‚Ä¢ ongratulate the circumci≈øed upon his being entred into the number of the Faithful, and then fit round about the Sofra or Tur
‚Ä¢ i≈øh Table, where they are entertained according to the manner of the circumci≈øed's Parents.

The liberalities which Rich Per≈øons be≈øtow at the Circumci≈øion of their Children do often mount to very great ≈øums; for be≈øides the Pre≈øents which they give to „Äà‚óä„Äâ number of Poor little Boys, who are ‚Ä¢ l≈øo then circumci≈øed then at their Co≈øts ‚Ä¢ s well as their own, and the entertainments they give almo≈øt to all tho≈øe who come thither, they likewi≈øe di≈øtribute great Alms to the poor of their Neighbourhood, that they may obtain from God ble≈ø≈øings for the new circumci≈øed, and for all his Family.

Now as for the particular Per≈øon, tho he ≈øometimes ≈øeems di≈ø≈øadvantaged by the ha≈øt, which may make judgment ra≈øh, yet that ha≈øt not being pa≈ø≈øionate, it happens not often; nor then likely, is his dammage therein wor≈øe, than with us, where after the ≈øu≈øpence, delay and Charge of ≈øuit, the over≈øight of a Lawyer, may with errour of pleading Ca≈øt a good Cau≈øe; ≈øo that after a Man hath been mi≈øerably detained to ≈øuch di≈øadvantages as his other affairs, as he had better have lo≈øt his Suit at fir≈øt; then doth it finally not ≈øo much on its own bare Right,
‚Ä¢ s upon the Advocate ≈øufficiency. The la≈øt notable point of their Judicature is, they have little fixt Law, and therewith flouri
‚Ä¢ hing make good that the mo≈øt Laws are in ‚Ä¢ he wor≈øt States. Yet they pretend to judge by the Alcoran; whereby the Opinion of Divine Authority does Countenance the≈øe Arbitrary Deqvi≈øions, which without ≈øome Authentive Law to ju≈øtify them would hard
‚Ä¢ y be endured. But as it is manife≈øt that the Alcoran is no Book of particular Law Ca≈øes, they pretend its Study does not informe the Judge lititerally, but by way of illuminetion, which not being given to ≈øecular Per≈øons, does neatly put lo≈øers off from referring them≈øelves to the Text: The Ju≈øtice being Arbitrary, makes it their Opinion the more to the purpo≈øe of the Publick. For the Judges knowing them≈øelves, but In≈øtruments of State, and that in its favour is their E≈øtabli≈øhment, they will ever judge by the Intere≈øt thereof, if not out of Hone≈øty, yet for their own Advancement.
