Europe. As for all the Princes of A≈øia, they have always the Aigrette very much In E≈øteem, but it mu≈øt not have the lea≈øt imperfection; and in ca≈øe it be the lea≈øt broken at the point, they make no accoun ‚Ä¢ of it, and it lo≈øes all its value. By the≈øe three Aigrettes of the Grand Seigniors Turbant, People know that the Grand Vizior is in the Army, becau≈øe that then he wears but two of them, and the thing is worthy of being remarked. When the Troop ‚Ä¢ are to March, the Grand Seignior draws up into Battalia, tho≈øe which are at Con≈øtantinople, and in the Neighbour-hood, and having the Great Vizio ‚Ä¢ by his ≈øide, he pre≈øents him to them for their General. The Souldiers then ≈øay not a word, and d ‚Ä¢ not make the u≈øual Salute, until that the Grand Seignior has cau≈øed one of the Agrettes to be taken out of his Turbant, to be put upon that of the Grand Vizior: Then all the Army Salute him, and own him for their General, and receive pay from him at the ≈øame time.

But to return, the Priviledge of Hor≈øe-tales extends at pre≈øent to the Ba≈øhawes of Natolia and R ‚Ä¢
mania, and they are all five equal in that point‚ñ™ But as for the Grand Vizior, who has a Magnificen ‚Ä¢ Court, an≈øwerable to the Grandeur of the Ma≈øte ‚Ä¢ he ≈øerves, and his Family is compo≈øed of above two thou≈øand Dome≈øticks. Though he be ≈øubject as we ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ as the other Ba≈øhaws, to undergo the Anger of hi ‚Ä¢ Prince, and con≈øtrain'd to give him his Head, wh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ he demands it; neverthele≈øs the Grand Seignior i ‚Ä¢ important affairs and which demand it, does yiel ‚Ä¢ much to the Sentiments of the Grand Vizior an ‚Ä¢ his Propo≈øitions in the Council are, as man Se ‚Ä¢
tences.
This it is renders his Power ≈øo ab≈øolute, that in all the Empires and Kingdoms in the World, there is not any Chief Mini≈øter who≈øe authority can match that of the Grand Vizior. Who≈øever comes to Vi≈øit him, he does not ri≈øe either „Äà‚óä„Äâ receive him, or conduct him, unle≈øs it be the Mufti who is Head of the Law, for whom the Grand Seignior him≈øelf ri≈øes al≈øo. But tins principally is worthy of being ob≈øerved, that as it only appertains to the Grand Vizior to propo≈øe all Affairs of Importance, he mu≈øt he careful not to ≈øtart any thing ungrateful to the Grand Seignior: For at the ≈øame time without making him any an≈øwer, he would be ≈øtrangled; upon this Maxim of the Ottoman Court, that nothing ought to be propo≈øed to the Prince, which he can be di≈øplea≈øed at.

But before I proceed on the other Mini≈øters, I will ≈øay ≈øomething of the Origine of the Grandees of the Port. Tho≈øe who po≈ø≈øe≈øs Places of tru≈øt, whether in the Serraglio, or in the Empire (unle≈øs it be Eunuchs, of whom more hereafter) come all generally from Children taken in War, or ≈øent by way of Pre≈øent from the Ba≈øhawes; and Tribute Children, that are taken at the Age of Nine or Ten years out of the Arms of their Mothers in all the Provinces, ≈øubdued by the Ottoman Prince, they ought all to be of Chri≈øtian Parents; and without reckoning the Slaves taken from the Enemy, one may ≈øee by the Regi≈øters alone of the Deme≈øne of Con≈øtantinople, that of both Sexes above twenty thou≈øand are brought thither every year. The le≈ø≈øer Tartars who make continual Incur≈øions into all the Territories that are Enemies of the Empire ≈øend 'em in Great Numbers; and the Grand Seignior having the Choice of all the≈øe young Children, the hand≈øome≈øt and the mo≈øt promi≈øing are di≈øtributed into divers Serraglio's, to be in≈øtructed there in the Law of Mahomet, and in all ≈øorts of Exerci≈øes, that of
Con≈øtantinople is filled with the flower of the≈øe la≈øt, and they are to be di≈øtingui≈øhed into two Orders. The fir≈øt and mo≈øt honourable is that of the Ichoglans, de≈øtined for the great Charges of the Empire; the ≈øecond Azamoglans, employed in Offices which only requite ≈øtrength of Body. The Ichoglans, are tho≈øe in whom, be≈øides the Perfections of Body, their Governors have di≈øcovered a fine Genius, proper for a fine Education, and for the rendring them capable one day to ≈øerve their Prince. They are in≈øtructed with great Care and a very ≈øevere Di≈øcipline, they pa≈øs through four Chambers called Oda, which are as four Cla≈ø≈øes, wherein they learn by order all that is ≈øuitable to Young Men, who are continually to attend upon a great Prince, and who are as his Pages and his Gentlemen. If they commit the lea≈øt fault they are rigorou≈øly puni≈øhed, and a Man had need to be endued with great Patience to attain to the fourth Oda, where they begin to breath. But the hopes of coming to the greate≈øt Honours and mo≈øt Eminent Offices, makes them ≈øuffer the barbarous Treatment of the Eunuchs, who are appointed for their Ma≈øters, and who are not ≈øparing to them of their Cudgels. Though it be an Ordinance of the Empire that all the≈øe Children be of Chri≈øtian Parents, of the mo≈øt Noble and the Hand≈øome≈øt that can be found, the Capi-Aga, or great Ma≈øter of the Serraglio, the fir≈øt of the White Eunuchs, who Commands in Chief the Ich ‚Ä¢ glans, does neverthele≈øs ≈øuffer ≈øome natural Turks to be introduced into their number, recommendable by their good Qualities: But this is rarely done, and that with a particular permi≈ø≈øion of the Prince, who loves much rather that the≈øe Children be all Renegado Chri≈øtians. This is the true O ‚Ä¢ igine of the Grandees of the Port; they are all Slaves, having no knowledge of their Paren ‚Ä¢ s they apply wholly their Affections to the Service of the Prince, who has rai≈øed them to a high Fortune.

The Ba≈øhaws are thus taken out of the Order of the Ichoglans, and the Name of Ba≈øhaw is only a Title of Honour and Dignity, common to all the Grandees of the Port, who di≈øtingui≈øh them≈øelves by the difference of their Places. The four Principal are the Vizier A≈øem, or Grand Vizier, the Chaimacan, the Ba≈øhaw of the Sea, and the Aga of the Janizar ‚Ä¢ es. The Authority of the≈øe four Ba≈øhaws is ≈øo great, that they ≈øometimes deprive their Sovereign of his Crown, to give it to whom they plea≈øe; as has hap
‚Ä¢ ed in our Age to two Emperours together, Mu≈øtapha and O≈øman the la≈øt of whom died in Pri≈øon by the infamous ‚Ä¢ and of an Executioner. But if the≈øe Ba≈øhaws do not under≈øtand aright how ‚Ä¢ o take their mea≈øures, they lo≈øe their Heads for the lea≈øt fault, the Grand Seig
‚Ä¢ ior ≈øeizing on all their E≈øtate upon their ‚Ä¢ eath, and taking their Children into ‚Ä¢ e Seraglio; very far from ≈øucceeding ‚Ä¢ nto the Riches and Offices of their Fa
‚Ä¢ ers, tho it ≈øhould be the Son of a Grand ‚Ä¢ izier, nay, or of the Emperour's Si≈øter; ‚Ä¢ ey can mount no higher than the ‚Ä¢ ace of a Captain of a Gally; the Poli
‚Ä¢ of the Turks not ≈øuffering that a Family
≈øhould render it ≈øelf Powerful from Father to Son, to deprive it of the means of ever being able to di≈øturb the State. One may hereby ≈øee, that the Fortune of the Ba≈øhaws, which is glittering for a time, is a wavering Fortune; on which neither Son nor Father, be he in what Credit he will, can make any foundation.

Having already ≈øpoken of the Vizier‚ñ™ I ≈øhall now proceed to the Chaimacan, who is the Captain and Governour of the City of Con≈øtantinople, Lieutenant of the Grand Vizier, but has no Authority bu ‚Ä¢ in his ab≈øence; then he performs all th ‚Ä¢ Functions of that important Office, Commands ab≈øolutely, and gives Audience t ‚Ä¢ Amba≈ø≈øadours. He is not ≈øubject as othe ‚Ä¢ Ba≈øhaws, to the har≈øh nece≈ø≈øity of givin ‚Ä¢ his Head; becau≈øe that if he does an ‚Ä¢
thing that is di≈øplea≈øing to the Gran ‚Ä¢ Seignior, he rejects the fault of it upo ‚Ä¢ the Grand Vizier, from whom he receiv ‚Ä¢ his Orders.

The Ba≈øhaw of the Sea is the Admin and Captain General of the Naval A ‚Ä¢
mies; the Beyes Governours of the M ‚Ä¢
ritime Provinces, and who are oblig ‚Ä¢ to maintain „Äà‚óä„Äâ Galleys of the Gra ‚Ä¢
Seignior, depend on his Orders, and mu≈øt put to Sea upon the fir≈øt Command he gives them.

The Janizary Aga, whom the Turks call Yongeri Aga≈øi, is the Collonel General of the Janizaries. This Office is very con≈øiderable, becau≈øe that the Turk ‚Ä¢ ≈øh Infantry pa≈ø≈øes at pre≈øent, for the greate≈øt part, under the name of Janizaries, tho the true Janizaries, who draw their In≈øtitution from Ottoman the Fir≈øt, and their great Priviledges from Ottoman the Third, make at pre≈øent but one Body of five and twenty thou≈øand men. They have fine Regulations among them, and are divided into ≈øeveral Chambers in great Hou≈øes they po≈ø≈øe≈øs, whether in Con≈øtantinople or other Places. The Order they keep there is ≈øo fine and exact in every thing, and ≈øo ≈øtrictly ob≈øerved, that they live le≈øs like Souldiers than Religious and Mona≈øticks; and tho they be not forbidden Matrimony, yet very ≈øeldom do they marry. The great Priviledges which they enjoy throughout all the Empire, where they are very much re≈øpected, makes many People to exempt them≈øelves from paving Taxes, and to di≈øcharge them≈øelves from ≈øome Publick Duties, to gain by money of the Officers,
who protect them, and make them pa≈øs for Janizaries: but they do not receive any Pay from the Prince; all their Advantages are limited to tho≈øe Priviledges, which are ≈øufficiently great. Thus by mingling the true Janizaries with the fal≈øe, their Number does now amount to above a hundred thou≈øand; and to reckon only tho≈øe who are effectually Janizaries, their Body has rendred it ≈øelf ≈øo formidable, that they have unthroned Ottoman Monarchs, and made the face of the Empire change in a moment. The Power of their Aga is very great, and no Body can approach the Prince after the manner he is allowed to do; for, he can come into the Pre≈øence of the Grand Seignior with his Arms free, and after a bold Gate and manner, whereas that all the Grandees of the Port without Exception, even the Grand Vizer, dare not appear there but with Arms acro≈øs, and their Hands upon one another on their Brea≈øt, for a ≈øign of a profound Submi≈ø≈øion.

The Beglerbeyes follow in Dignity the four principal Ba≈øhaws, and are as ≈øo many Sovereigns in the general Governments of the Empire, whereof the Grand Seignior gives them the Command. The≈øe Grand Ba≈øhaws have under them Sangiacbeys,
who are Governours of Sangiacs or particular Provinces, as the Sangiacbey of Salonica or of Morea.
Thus having mentioned the≈øe Principal Officers, and the Janizaries, I will proceed to give an account of the Spahees, Zaims, and Ghaoax's.

The Spahees, who make a Body of about fifteen thou≈øand men, are a ≈øort of Cavaliers, who would pa≈øs for the Nobility of the Country, and boa≈øt very much of their Bravery: they live upon certain Timarrits or Fewds given them by the Grand Seignior for term of life, as a Reward for Services, but with an Obligation to ≈øerve on Hor≈øe-back well appointed, where≈øoever they ≈øhall be ≈øummoned. The≈øe Timarres cannot be taken from them unle≈øs they are wanting in their Duty, which is to be at the Army when the Grand Vizier goes thither in Per≈øon. They live the mo≈øt happy of all the Ottoman Empire, and like petty Sovereigns in the Places where they command.

The Zaims differ little from the Spahees, and enjoy, as well as they, the Command and Revenue of certain Fiefs given them by the Grand Seignior. There is a great number of them throughout all the Empire,
and they e≈øteem them≈øelves as Lords & Barons of the Country. The Zaims and the Spahis are they who compo≈øe the Cavalry of the Turks, and they know how many Hor≈øes they are to furni≈øh according to the Revenue of their Timars.

The Chaoux, or Chiaous Ba≈øhaw, is the Head of all the Chaoux of the Empire, who carry the Commands of the Prince within and without the State, and are ≈øent upon Emba≈ø≈øies, tho in the bottom they are only mere Me≈ø≈øengers. Pri≈øoners of Quality are commonly committed to their Keeping, and they never ≈øuffer them out of ≈øight.

The≈øe are the principal Offices and Dignities of the Empire, all po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by People who are taken out of the Order of the Ichoglans. I now come to the Officers of the Serraglio, where the Eunuchs are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the principal Places of Tru≈øt.

There be two Orders of the Eunuchs; there are tho≈øe who are white, who are meerly cut, and there are tho≈øe who are black, who are ≈øhaved even with the Belly. Both are ≈øevere, fanta≈øtical, and jealous, and u≈øe all tho≈øe cruelly who are under their Charge. There is a prodigious number of them both in Con≈øtantinople
and all the Empire, and generally through all the Ea≈øt, where there is no private Per≈øon, in ca≈øe he has but any E≈øtate, but keeps an Eunuch or two as a Guard to his Wives. This it is that makes the great Trade of Eunuchs in ≈øeveral Parts of A≈øa and Africa; and only in the Kingdom of Goleonda, a ≈ømall Territory in the Ea≈øt-Indies, there has been known to be made in one Year two and twenty thou≈øand. In tho≈øe Parts mo≈øt Fathers and Mothers who are poor, and have no kindne≈øs for their Children, whom they fear they ≈øhall not be able to provide Su≈øtenance for, if the lea≈øt ≈øcarcity of Victuals ≈øhould happen, fell them to Merchants, who afterwards cau≈øe them to be cut, and ≈øometimes ≈øhaved ≈øheer off. Some of tho≈øe who have nothing left, when they are to make Water, are con≈øtrained to make u≈øe of a Quill or Tap‚ñ™ and to carry it at the bottom of the Belly. As few recover from ≈øo dangerous an Operation, it renders them much dearer than the others, and they are ≈øold in Per≈øia and Turkey at the rare of ≈øix hundred Crowns a Man; a hundred, or a hundred and fifty, is the price of common Eunuchs. Now for the furni≈øhing all Turkey, all Per≈øia, all the Indies, and all the
Provinces of Africa, it is ea≈øie to judge that they mu≈øt needs come by thou≈øands from diver≈øe Places. The Kingdom of Golconda in the Penin≈øula, on this ≈øide the Ganges, and tho≈øe of A≈ø≈øan, Boutan, Arachan, and Pegu beyond it, furni≈øh a prodigious number of them. All the≈øe Eunuchs are white and tawny. The black Eunuchs, who come from Africa in a far le≈ø≈øer number, are, as I have ≈øaid, much dearer. The mo≈øt deformed are tho≈øe which co≈øt the mo≈øt, their extreme Ugline≈øs being a Beauty to them in their kind. A flat No≈øe, a di≈ømal Look, a great Mouth, thick Lips, black Teeth and at a di≈øtance from one another, for commonly the Moors have fine Teeth, are Advantages for the Merchants who ≈øell them. The Serraglio of Con≈øtaminople is filled with the≈øe two ≈øorts of Eunuchs. The black are appointed as a Guard to the Apartment of Women, and ≈øent to the Court by the Ba≈øhaws of Grand Cairo. The white ≈øomething le≈øs ≈øavage, and who have been brought up with ≈øome Care, are for the Quarter of the Grand Seignior.

The four principal Eunuchs, who approach the Per≈øon of the Prince, are the Hazodabachaio, the Cha≈ønardeerba≈øhaw,
the Kilargiba≈øhaw, and the Sarai Aga≈øi, who have over them the Capi-Aga, who is the Intendant of all the Chambers in chief of the Ichoglans: they commonly ≈øucceed one another; that is to ≈øay, the Sarai-Aga≈øi to the Kilargiba≈øhaw, he to Cha≈ønadarba≈øhaw, this la≈øt to Hazodabachi, and finally, the Hazodabachi to the Capi-Aga, who is ever the olde≈øt in Service of the white Eunuchs.

The Capi-Aga or Capon Aga≈øi, is as the Lord High Steward of the Serraglio, is the fir≈øt in Dignity and in Credit of all the white Eunuchs, and is ever near the Per≈øon of the Grand Seignior be he where he will. He it is who introduces Amba≈ø≈øadors to the Audience; and all the great Affairs pa≈ø≈øing through his Hands to come to tho≈øe of the Prince, his Office renders him nece≈ø≈øary to all the others, and acquires him rich Pre≈øents. All tho≈øe who make any to the Grand Seignior ought to addre≈øs them≈øelves al≈øo to the Capi-Aga for the pre≈øenting them to his Highne≈øs, from whence accrew to him very great Advantages. No Body can enter into the Apartment of the Emperour nor go out from thence without his Order: and when the Grand Vizier has a Mind to ≈øpeak to him, he mu≈øt be introduced by
the Capi-Aga. Whether by Day or Night if any ha≈øty Bu≈øine≈øs does happen whereof the Vizier would give Notice to the Grand Seignior by Writing, the Capi Aga mu≈øt receive it and return the An≈øwer. He wears a Turbant in the Serraglio, and goes every whereon Hor≈øeback by a Priviledge particularly annexed to his Office. He accompanies the Grand Seignior, but ≈øtays at the Door, having no more Command in that Place. The Caravan of Cairo is the mo≈øt numerous and mo≈øt con≈øiderable of all th ‚Ä¢ Caravans which go to Mecca. The Caravan Ba≈øhi, who is Captain thereof, ha ‚Ä¢ ≈øometimes two hundred thou≈øand Crown ‚Ä¢ profit at his Return; and there is grea ‚Ä¢ caballing for his place, which is at th ‚Ä¢
Ba≈øhaws Di≈øpo≈øal, and is ≈øeldom give ‚Ä¢ but to him that bids mo≈øt. The Captai ‚Ä¢ of this Caravan is al≈øo Ma≈øter of the Waters
that are brought into the Ci≈øterns, it is by his Order that they are di≈øtributed; and as this Di≈øtribution is equal for the Poor and for the Rich; and if this la≈øt will have beyond what he is ordered, he mu≈øt pay for it dearly, and the Captain who taxes it at what rate he plea≈øes rai≈øes a con≈øiderable profit.

But let us return to the Grand Seignior's Pre≈øent. The Tent and Carpet which he ≈øends are two pieces equally precious, both for the Beauty of the Stuff and the Riches that are added to it. The Tapi≈øtry is to cover the Tomb of Mahomet, and the Tent which is ≈øet up again≈øt the Mo≈øch is for the Cheq, who ≈øtirs not from thence during the ≈øeventeen days Devotion. That High Prie≈øt of the Law of Mahomet has found the ≈øecret to rai≈øe immen≈øe Sums by this Tapi≈øtry and Tent; every Year, and when the new Pre≈øent ‚Ä¢ s arriv'd from the Grand Seignior, he ‚Ä¢ ends as a ≈øingular Favour pieces of the Courtin of the old Tent to ≈øeveral Mahometan Princes, from whom, in return, ‚Ä¢ e receives magnificent Pre≈øents. This Courtin which reaches all about the ‚Ä¢ ut ≈øide of the Tent, to hinder tho≈øe ‚Ä¢ rom being ≈øeen that are within, is compo≈øed
≈øeveral pieces, ≈øix foot high, and of a great length; and the Cheq gives tho≈øe Princes to under≈øtand, that by fa≈øtening one of tho≈øe Pieces to their Tents when they go to War again≈øt tho≈ø ‚Ä¢ whom they con≈øider as Infidels, they wil ‚Ä¢ be attended with all the happy Succe≈ø ‚Ä¢ imaginable, and will not be long befor ‚Ä¢ they gain the Victory. It mu≈øt be ≈øom ‚Ä¢ great Monarch, as the Great Kam o ‚Ä¢
Tartary, or the Great Mogol, to whom he ≈øends either the whole Courtin ‚Ä¢ Tent, or Tapi≈øtry, which he does onc ‚Ä¢ in ten or twelve Years, ≈øometimes t ‚Ä¢ the one, ≈øometimes to the other. Arte ‚Ä¢ that Aurengezebe, King of the Indies
„Äà‚óä„Äâ and whom otherwi≈øe we call the Grea ‚Ä¢
Mogol, was ≈øetled upon the Throne, th ‚Ä¢
Cheq ≈øent him the whole Courtain o ‚Ä¢ the Tent; and great Joy was there a ‚Ä¢ that Court that the King had receive ‚Ä¢ from ≈øo Holy a Place, as they call it ≈øo magnificent a Pre≈øent. The Cheq pre≈øently after ta≈øted of the Royal Liberality of that great Monarch, one of th ‚Ä¢ riche≈øt and mo≈øt potent of the Univer≈øe And at this rate it is that the chief of th ‚Ä¢ Religion of Mahomet, who has a kin ‚Ä¢ of Dominion over all the Members
knows how to render them u≈øeful, and found the means of enriching him≈øelf at the Co≈øts of all the Mahometan Princes and People.

I do not doubt but that tho≈øe who have written of the Mahometan Religion, have made mention of the Pilgrimage of Mecca, which is one of its e≈ø≈øential Parts, wherefore I ≈øhall not enlarge farther upon that matter. I will only make three Remarks, taken out of an Original of one of the mo≈øt Learned in the Rubricks of the Law of Mahomet. The fir≈øt is, that by an ancient Tradition the Turks believe that Mecca is the Place where God commanded Abraham to build him an Hou≈øe; that while he was there all Nations came to vi≈øit him in Crowds; and that it is al≈øo the ≈øame Place where Mahomet received the Alcoran from Heaven. The ≈øecond regards the Commands made to all the Mahometans, to go once in their Life time a Pilgrimage to Mecca; for it is to be ob≈øerved, that this Obligation does not extend to the poor People, who have nothing whereon ab≈øolutely to live, and who would make their Family ≈øuffer by their ab≈øence, having nothing to leave them for their
Maintenance. The third Remark is, touching the preference of the two Cities of Mecca and Medina. The fir≈øt is the Place of Mahomet's Birth, which he had a de≈øign to have honoured and celebrated by this famous Pilgrimage, to which he obliges all tho≈øe of his Law The ≈øecond is the Place of the Sepulture of which they tell many Fables. Mahomet in his Alcoran only Orders the going to Mecca, where there are no other Relicks of this fal≈øe Prophet than one of hi ‚Ä¢ Slippers: and the Doctors of the Law do al≈øo grant, that there is no Obligation to go to Medina, and that withou ‚Ä¢ ≈øeeing that City, the Command of Mahomet is fulfilled.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Original, and Hi≈øtory of the Turks.
div.p:
THO the Turks have acquired ≈øo va≈øt an Empire, yet their Original is ≈øo ob≈øcure, that what we know of it is rather Conjecture than any certain Account. However, this is allowed of by all hands, that they were a People of Scythia, who, either compelled by Famine, or the Sword of their Neighbours, to abandon their own Countrey, pa≈ø≈øed through the Streights of the Ca≈øpian Mountains, and ≈øubdued and ≈øettled them≈øelves in Armenia the Greater; thereupon called Turcomania, as it is at this day. Thus continued they to acquire Reputation, and multiply their Acce≈ø≈øions, profe≈ø≈øing Pagaini≈øm, and living in wandring Troops, after the manner of the Scythian Nomades. The Saracen Empire being upon its declen≈øion, nay, brought almo≈øt to the la≈øt Ga≈øp, by the Divi≈øion of its own Princes; Mahomet, the Sultan of Per≈øia being overpower ‚Ä¢ d
by the Caliph of Babylon, demanded Succours of the Turks, from whom receiving three thou≈øand Souldiers, under the Conduct of Tangrolipix, the Chief of the Seleuccian Family, he overthrew the Caliph by his means. Neverthele≈øs, he would have con≈øtrained the Turk to have continued in his Service, which occa≈øioned ≈øo great a Breach, as that it came unto a Battel. Tangrolipix had the Victory, was by both Armies elected Sultan, conquered the Caliph of Babylon, which he added to his Dominions of Per≈øia. About this time did the Turk embrace the Mahometan Religion, being two hundred and fourteen years after their Sally out of Scithia. Tangrolipix was ≈øucceeded by his Son Axan, who con≈øented that Cutlu Mu≈øes, and his Kin≈øman, both of his Blood, ≈øhould enjoy in ab≈øolute Sovereignty what they ≈øhould conquer from the Grecian Emperour: and they receiving Aid accordingly from him for that purpo≈øe, ≈øubdued Media, much of Armenia, Cappadocia, Pontus, Bithinia, and the greater part of the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia. This Sultan moreover be≈øtowed the Cities of Dama≈øcus and Aleppo, with their Territories, upon two other of
his Kin≈ømen, Duccot and Melich, upon condition of paying him Homage, and al≈øo promi≈øing them all they could gain from the Saracens, and allowing them Forces accordingly, they rendred them≈øelves Ma≈øters of the greater Part of Syria; but in a ≈øhort while after, were expelled thence, as al≈øo out of the mo≈øt part of A≈øia the le≈ø≈øer, by Godfrey of Bullen, and by him and his Chri≈øtians driven to the more Ea≈øterly Parts of their Dominions. After the Death of Cutlu Mu≈øes, his Son Solyman made a vigorous oppo≈øition again≈øt the We≈øtern Chri≈øtians; after his Death, his Son Mahomet had a War, and then a Peace with Ma≈øut Sultan of Iconium. This Ma≈øut having gotten po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the whole Turki≈øh Kingdom in that part of A≈øia, at his Death divided it among≈øt his three Sons. To Galiza≈øthan he gave the Regal City of Iconium, with the under Provinces; to Jagupa≈øan, A na≈øta and Anevra, with part of Cappadocia and the Territories adjacent: but to Daduns he gave the ample Cities of Cae≈øaria and Seba≈øtia, and all the large Neighbouring Territories, being before part of the Greek, Empire. But the≈øe Brethren fell
at odds with one another, and the elde≈øt di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Dadune of his Patrimony, and did the like with Jacupa≈øan. After which he invaded the adjoyning Parts of the Greek Empire, and in a Battel overthrew Emmanuel Comnenus, a valiant, but unfortunate Emperour; who being dead, he conquered Phrygia, with divers Frontier Cities and Ca≈øtles. Sultan dying in a very old Age, left behind him four Sons, Ma≈øut, Coppatine, Reucratine, and Chaicho≈øroes. To Ma≈øut he bequeathed Ama≈øa, Ancyra, Dorileum, with ≈øeveral Cities more of Pontus; to Coppatine, Melitene, Ce≈øaria, Taxaria; to Reucratine, Amin≈øum, Docea, with the Sea-bordring Cities; but to Chaico≈øroes, (be≈øides the Regal Seat of Iconium) Lycaonia, Pamphilia, and the bordering Countries as far as Cotyanium, with the Title of Sultan. But the≈øe falling likewi≈øe into Di≈ø≈øention among them≈øelves, upon Reucratine and Ma≈øut's contending in Arms for Coppatine's Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, who dyed not long after his Father. But Fortune favouring Reucratine, he invaded the Sultan, took from him Iconium, drove him out of his Dominions, and became ≈øole Sovereign. This Branch was not alone ≈øucce≈øsful;
for, the Race of Ducat and Melech recovered all Syria under the Conduct of the renowned Saladine, and joyned Egypt to his Empire, leaving nine Sons behind, all murdered, but one, by Saphradine their Uncle, that one e≈øcaping by the means of his Fathers Favourites, and was al≈øo called Saphradine and Sultan of Aleppo. From that treacherous Saphradine de≈øcended Meleden, Sultan of Egypt, and Coradin, Sultan of Dama≈øcus and Jeru≈øalem. Tho the va≈øt Dominions of Saladin were thus again rent in pieces, yet ≈øtill were they po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by Branches of the Selzuccian Family, untill that the Mamulucks ≈øtrip'd them of Egypt, and the Tartars drove them out of Syria; and the Turki≈øh Empire which Tangralipix e≈øtabli≈øhed in Per≈øia and tho≈øe Ea≈øtern Countries, was utterly ≈øubverted by the Tartars after it had continued a hundred and ≈øeventy Years. The≈øe Tartars were a cruel barbarous People, dwelling on the North of the Mountain Cauca≈øus, who compelled by Famine upon the In≈øtances of one Zingis a Prophet of theirs, and who was dignified with the Title of Great Cham, like a violent Deluge broke over the Bounds of tho≈øe Mountains
wherein they had for many Ages been confined, and over run all the Ea≈øtern Parts of A≈øia as far as the great Ocean. Heccata his Son, built Quin≈øay in China, and Cambala in Cathaia, which la≈øt he made the Seat of his Empire. By his numerous Armies he ≈øubdued the Araco≈øians, Margians, Medes, Per≈øians, Parthians, A≈ø≈øyrians, Me≈øopotamians, Armenians, Colchians, and Iberians, compelling the Turks to abandon tho≈øe Countries. But the≈øe la≈øt under Aladine one of the Selzuccian Family, joyning with the People of le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, took Cilicia from the Greeks with the Places bordering; fir≈øt ≈øetling the Seat of their new Kingdom in Seba≈øtia, and afterwards at Iconium. Aladine left behind him two Sons, Azadine and Jathatine; but they falling at Di≈øcord, the elder con≈øtrained the younger into Bani≈øhment. But Jathatine returned after Azadine's Death, and was owned for Sultan; but ≈øhortly after ≈ølain in ≈øingle Combate by Theodorus La≈øcaes the Greek Emperour. Another of the ≈øame Name was his Succe≈ø≈øor, but defeated by the victorious Tartars, and forced out of Iconium: the Turks were finally compelled to pay them Tribute, and become
‚Ä¢ heir Subjects. Jathatine being dead in Exile, the great Cham divided his Kingdom between Ma≈øut and Cei-Cubades, who were both de≈øcended of the Selzuccian Family, re≈øerving a Tribute from them to him≈øelf. Thus was this great and mighty Empire extingui≈øh'd in Egypt by the Mammalucks, and in both great and le≈ø≈øer A≈øia by the Tartars. But falling into Divi≈øions, every one got a ≈øhare, and turned the Monarchy of their new Ma≈øters into an Anarchy. The ba≈øer ≈øort having got Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Streights of the Mountains, did prove trouble≈øome Neighbours to the Chri≈øtians by their frequent Incur≈øions; and having given a total Defeat to the Emperour's Lieutenant in Paphlagonia, they over-ran all the Country unto the River Sangarius, ≈øubduing Pontus and Galatia; and extending their Conque≈øts Southward unto the Lycian and Carian Seas, and to the River Eurimedon, which they divided into ≈øeveral Toparchyes. Of the two fore-named Princes, Ma≈øut died without I≈ø≈øue, but Ceicubades was ≈øucceeded by his Son Aladin, titular Lord of the Whole, though a Tributary to the Tartar, and the la≈øt of the Selzuccian Family. Upon
his Death the Sovereignty was u≈øurped, but not long po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, by Sahib the head Vi≈øier; the Grandees ≈øharing among them the Remainder of that di≈ømembred Kingdom as they had done the re≈øt.

Ottoman, among the≈øe, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Siguta, a ≈ømall Seigniory in Bithynia, be≈øtowed by Aladm the fir≈øt upon his Father Ertogriel, the Son of Solyman, one of the Oguzian Family, and once Sultan of Machan. Whom, fear of the Traytors making him abandon his Kingdom, He for a long while led a wandring life, with uncertain Fortunes. But Ertogriel coming into the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, de≈øired Aladine to be≈øtow upon him ≈øome corner of ≈øo va≈øt a Kingdom for him and his Families Habitation. Aladin remembring his own Sufferings, and the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance he had received from Ertogriel in a certain Encounter, a≈ø≈øigned him ≈øome few Lands, and a Command upon the Frontier; where he lived long in great tranquility, and much beloved both by the Turks and Chri≈øtians, who were his Neighbours. Dying in the Year 1289, he left three Sons, Jundas, Saragatin, and this Ottoman, who was elected by the Oguzians
for their Governour. His People having ≈øuffered ≈øome outrages from the Chri≈øtians, he thereupon ≈øurprized ≈øeveral of their Ca≈øtles, defeated the Greeks in ≈øundry Rencounters, took from them the City of Nice, and upon the Death of Aladin, took upon him the Title of Sultan, making Neapolis the Seat of his Kingdom, in the year 1300, where is to be placed the fir≈øt Date of the Ottoman Government. During his Reign of ≈øeven and twenty years, he annexed Bithynia, Cappadocia, and mo≈øt of the Fortre≈ø≈øes that confine upon the Euxine Sea, unto his Crown. His Succe≈ø≈øor was his Son Orchanes, who took the great City of Pru≈øe, and made it his Re≈øidence. Having made va≈øt Additions to his Dominions, he departed this Life, in the two and thirtieth Year of his Reign, leaving his Scepter to Amurath his Son. He perceiving the Greeks to be at Di≈øcord among them≈øelves, fir≈øt pa≈ø≈øed over the Streights into Europe, took Abydosf and Callippolis, with the whole Cher≈øone≈øus; and pu≈øhing on his Conque≈øts into Thracia, he took Philippolis and Adrianople; and ≈øtill continuing his victorious Career, ≈øubdued
Servia and Bulgaria, pa≈ø≈øed into the upper My≈øia, was at length ≈øtabbed by a Common-Souldier, in the one and thirtieth Year of his Reign, and leaving his va≈øt Dominions and Acqu≈øitions to Bajazet his Son. This Bajazet ≈øubdued Phocis with the large≈øt part of Greece, and twice be≈øieged Con≈øtautinople, though in vain. Being at length taken by Tamerlane, and carry'd about in an iron Cage. He beat out his own Brains in the Year 1399, being ≈øucceeded by his Son Callepine, to whom ≈øome attribute ≈øix Years of Government, which others will not allow, but give the Succe≈ø≈øion to his younge≈øt Son Mahomet; the Rea≈øon of this Diver≈øity proceeding from the Suppre≈ø≈øion of the Turk ‚Ä¢ ≈øt Kingdom by the Tartars. Bajazet having many Sons, they and other Mahemetans di≈ømembred again this va≈øt Empire, and po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd them≈øelves of ≈øeveral Provinces, but were all at length obtained and re-united again by Mahomet, who added to them by Conque≈øt, Dacia, Walachia, the greate≈øt part of Sclavonia, Macedonia, as far as unto the Ionian Sea. He removed the Seat of his Empire from Pru≈øa unto Adrianople, where he departed
this Life, after he had reigned ≈øeventeen Years, reckoning from the Death of his Father. He was ≈øucceeded by his Son Amarath the Second: this Prince conquered Epyrus, Oetolia, Attica, Baeotia, Achaia, and The≈ø≈øalonica. After he had ruled ≈øeven and twenty Years his Son Mahomet the Second ruled in his ≈øtead, and by his brave Performances acquired the Name of Great, utterly ≈øubverting the Greek Empire, taking Con≈øtantinople the Imperial City, the Emperour Con≈øtantine being trod to Death by the Crowd of People in Adrianople Gate; and thus gained he the Title of Emperour. He al≈øo conquered the Empire of Trabezond which Alexius Comnenus had erected there, at ≈øuch time as the Greeks did lo≈øe their European Empire to the Latins. He al≈øo ≈øubdued Athens, Corinth, all Peloponne≈øus, Bo≈øna, Lemnos, Euloera, Mitylen, &c. and died in the one and thirtieth year of his Reign, it being much ≈øu≈øpected he was poy≈øoned. Bajazet the Second, his Son, having put a Period to his Wars with his Brother, ≈øubdued all Cilicia, part of Armenia, with the re≈øt of Cappadocia, which before appertained to
the Carmanian Kingdom. But his Inva≈øion of Syria was not attended with that Succe≈øs. After which, he bent his Forces again≈øt the Venetians, took from them Naupactus, Methona, Dyrrachium, and almo≈øt de≈øolated Dalmatia. But Selym, his Son and Succe≈ø≈øor, at length procured a Jew to poy≈øon him in the ≈øix and thirtieth year of his Reign. This Selym ≈øubdued all Syria, Egypt, and Arabia; and after he had reigned eight years, died of a mo≈øt loath≈øome Di≈øea≈øe, ju≈øt as he was entertaining De≈øigns of invading the Chri≈øtians. His Son Solyman reigned in his ≈øtead, and took Rhodes, over-run Hungary ≈øeveral times, took Buda, Strigonium, Alba Regalis, drove the Per≈øians out of Tauris, annexed Babylon with the Provinces of Media, Me≈øopotamia, and A≈ø≈øyria, to his Empire, extended his Conque≈øts into Arabia, and brought the Portugals in the Indies within the Reach, of his Ambition. He died in the ≈øix and fortieth Year of his Reign, leaving his Scepter to Selym the Second, the only Son he had then left unmurthered. This Selym won Cyprus from the Venetians by his Lieutenants, enlarged his Bounds with
Walachia, Moldavia, and the Kingdom of Tunis, reigned eight years, and was ≈øucceeded by Amurath the Third, who during his Reign of nineteen Years, performed nothing of any great Con≈øideration. Neither was Mahomet the Third, his Son, a Souldier; his Reign of eight years being inglorious, and chiefly ≈øpent in ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing dome≈øtick Broils and inte≈øtine Rebellions. Upon Mahomet the Third's Death his Son Achmet, then but fifteen years old, was ≈øaluted Emperour. This Princes Reign was as un≈øucce≈øsful as that of his immediate Predece≈ø≈øor, the Per≈øian King in the Beginning of it recovering almo≈øt all from him that the Turks had taken from his Ance≈øtors: for the Sophi, in Conjunction with Caracan the Head of a Rebellion then in Turkey, defeated Cicala Ba≈ø≈øa in a ≈øet Battel, with the lo≈øs of almo≈øt all his Turks, taking the Ba≈øhaw's Son Pri≈øoner, and inviting, by ≈øecret Me≈ø≈øengers, the bordering Nations to revolt from the Turki≈øh ≈øubjection, and again defeated the ≈øame Ba≈ø≈øa, who returned with a va≈øt Army into tho≈øe Parts, in two ≈øet Battels, wherein ≈øeventy thou≈øand Turks
were ≈ølain. The≈øe Succe≈ø≈øes of the Per≈øians created a mighty terrour over all Turkey, even in Con≈øtantinople it ≈øelf, it being bruited, that he was marching apace in the Head of an hundred thou≈øand men, and that Bagagi, a male-contented Ba≈ø≈øa, was joyned with him; Hereupon Cicala Ba≈øhaw was again di≈øpatched with Forces again≈øt the Sophi and the A≈øian Rebels, but was again defeated by the Per≈øian Monarch, and the City of Babylon, now called Bagdat taken. Nor the le≈øs ≈øucce≈øsful were the Ottoman Troops in Hungary, the Imperiali≈øts routing them in ≈øeveral Occa≈øions, which, with the ≈øeveral Defeats the Rebel Hungarians received in diver≈øe Occa≈øions, brought the Turks to more humble thoughts, and made way for a Peace between the two Empires.

Some time after, a Peace was al≈øo concluded by the Grand Seignior, with the Per≈øian Amba≈ø≈øador, then re≈øident at the Port, but the Sophi thinking it to be upon di≈øhonourable terms, was ≈øo far from ratifying it, that he cau≈øed his Mini≈øter's Head to be cut off, at his fir≈øt ≈øetting foot in Per≈øia.

In the mean while, the Turki≈øh Navigation was extreamly annoyed by Chri≈øtian Cor≈øairs, who took their Ships, plundered their I≈ølands, and Sea Coa≈øts, and carried many of the Grand Seignior's Subjects away captive.

In this Sultan's time was a great Plague at Con≈øtantinople, de≈øtroying many thou≈øands, of People every day, and almo≈øt de≈øolating the whole City. And thus after an unea≈øie and un≈øucce≈øsful Reign, Ackmet died, having lived thirteen years, and ≈øwayed the Scepter fifteen, and was ≈øucceeded by his Brother Mu≈øtapha, by rea≈øon of O≈øman, his Son's Minority. But this Mu≈øtapha proving cruel, not only to his own Subjects, but to Foreigners; impri≈øoning, upon ≈øome ≈ølight pretexts, the French Amba≈ø≈øadour, and torturing his Servants; clapping al≈øo young O≈øman, the right Heir, and his Brethren into Chains; which gave ≈øuch Provocation, that the Grand Vizier at his return from the War of Per≈øia, freed O≈øman out of Pri≈øon, and put Mu≈øtapha in his place; where we will let him remain until we have ≈øet down ≈øome Occurrences of the Reign of O≈øman, who was not full thirteen years
of Age when he was advanced to the Throne.

The fir≈øt thing he did was to promi≈øe redre≈øs for the Affront that the French Crown had received in the Per≈øon of it's Amba≈ø≈øadour. His Reign was al≈øo u≈øhered in by a great Victory he gain'd by one of the Ba≈øhaws over the Per≈øians, which was occa≈øioned by an Inva≈øion o ‚Ä¢
Per≈øia it ≈øelf, by which means ≈øeveral of its Provinces were de≈øolated by Fire and Sword, which forced the Sophi to a di≈øhonourable and di≈øadvantageous Peace; the Per≈øians ≈øending two hundred Camels laden with ≈øilk as a Tribute to the Grand Seignir for many years after.

O≈øman abetted and promi≈øed a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to Bethlem Gabor, Prince of Tran≈øilvania, in be De≈øigns he entertained again≈øt the Em

In the year 1670. During the≈øe Occurrences, the Malte≈øe and Signiore≈øe Cor≈øairs meeting with the Alexandria Fleet, they attacked them, and took four Gallions and two Saicks, being a Prize of ine≈øtimable value.

As for Action, there was little pa≈ø≈øed, the Grand Seignior dedicating the Year 1675 wholly to Mirth and Jollitry upon the account of the Circumci≈øion of his Son. In 1676 the Grand Vizier Achmet died, in the forty ≈øeventh Year of his Age, and fifteenth Year and eighth Day of his Government, after he had upon every Expedition, enlarged the Bounds of he Empire, overcome New-ha≈øel or Oywar, and annexed to it a con≈øiderable part of Hungary, concluded the War with Venice after twenty ≈øeven years Continuance, by an entire and total Subjection of

In the mean while the Ba≈øhaw of Grand Cairo having laid too heavy Taxes upon the People, they broke out into a Rebellion, a≈ø≈øaulted the Ba≈øhaw, and committed him to Pri≈øon; but means were quickly found by the Ottoman Court to appea≈øe the People, which was chiefly brough ‚Ä¢ about by removing the Ba≈øhaw to the Government of Candia.

He u≈øhered in his Government by Actions o ‚Ä¢ Ju≈øtice upon ≈øeveral Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors, cutting off the Pay-ma≈øter's Head for bringing fal≈øe Money into the Exchequer, and di≈øplacing and depo≈øing ≈øuch Mini≈øters a ‚Ä¢
he had found corrupted or remi≈øs in their Duty. But his carriage towards Foreign Mini≈øters was arrogant and intolerable, refu≈øing the French Amba≈ø≈øadour to have his Stool upon the Sofra at Audience, which occa≈øion'd great. During the≈øe Tran≈øactions there being no pro≈øpect of an Accommodation with Poland, great Preparations were made for the carrying on the War. In the mean while, the mi≈øunder≈øtanding between the Grand Vizier and the French Amba≈ø≈øadour augmenting daily more and more about the Sofra, he was treated by tho≈øe Infidels in ≈øuch manner as in n ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ wi≈øe ≈øuted with his Character, and the Breach became the greater by the Enterprize of Mon≈øieur d ‚Ä¢ Que≈øne, the French Admiral, at Chio, in the Yea ‚Ä¢ 1680; for the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King being then a ‚Ä¢ Wars with the Tripolins, ≈øeven of tho≈øe Cor≈øairs had taken refuge in the Port of Chio, an I≈øland belonging to the Grand Seignior, Mon≈øieur de Que≈øne re≈øolutely entred the Port with his Gallies, and after having batter'd down a great part of the Ca≈øtle, and demoli≈øhed many magnificent Fabricks, he ≈øunk tw ‚Ä¢ of the Ships, took one, and fired the re≈øt, lo≈øing i ‚Ä¢ this action but thirty of his men, tho of the Turk ‚Ä¢

div.head: The Pre≈øent State of Hungary.
div.p:
THe Kingdom of Hungary did anciently contain, be≈øides the Countrey properly ≈øo called, the large Provinces of Dalmatia, Croatia, Schlavonia, Bo≈ønia, Servia, Bulgaria, Halibia, Lodomeria and Cumania, be≈øides Tran≈øylvania, and others; thus extending from the Euxine Sea as far as Au≈øtria, and from the Adriatick as far as the Coa≈øts of Poland: But is now confined within much narrower limits, being bounded on the South with the River Seevus, and the Dukedomes of Servia and Croatia; on the Ea≈øt with Tran≈øylvania; on the North with the Carpathian Mountains, which ≈øepa
‚Ä¢ ate it from Poland and Moravia; and on ‚Ä¢ he We≈øt with the Arch-Dukedom of Au≈øtria and the Dukedome of Styria. So ‚Ä¢ hat its greate≈øt length from the head of
‚Ä¢ ibi≈øcus, or the Tei≈ø≈øe, to the mouth of ‚Ä¢ he Mun, will amount to about ≈øixty
‚Ä¢ erman miles, and its breadth to near as ‚Ä¢ uch.

The air of Hungary agrees well enough with the con≈øtitution of the Natives, though unwhole≈øome, and hardly tolerable to ≈øtrangers: In the middle of the day in Summer being exce≈ø≈øive hot and ≈øoultry, and at midnight as in≈øufferably cold and piercing. The frequency of Springs and Rivers which refre≈øh and water every part of the Kingdom, render the ≈øoil as fertile as any part of the Univer≈øe. By the≈øe means are fed tho≈øe va≈øt numbers of Cattle, which are thence driven to Vienna, Italy, and other neigh ‚Ä¢ bouring Countreys, there having been known in one year alone that forty thou≈øand yoak of Oxen, ready for th ‚Ä¢ ≈ølaughter, have pa≈ø≈øed the Roads between Vienna and Hungary. Another argument of its fertility may be draw from its maintaining, as it has done, fo ‚Ä¢ ≈øo long tho≈øe numerous Armies of th ‚Ä¢ Rebels, Turks and Imperiali≈øts. The F ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ re≈øts and Woods breed ≈øuch plenty „Äà‚óä„Äâ all ≈øorts of Veni≈øon, that a hundred an ‚Ä¢ twenty Harts have been known to hav ‚Ä¢ been killed at one hunting; and th ‚Ä¢ abundance makes them never troub ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ them≈øelves to pre≈øerve the Game b ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Parks and Inclo≈øures. And ≈øuch plen ‚Ä¢ have they of Phea≈øants, Patridges, Woo ‚Ä¢
cocks, and other ≈øorts of the mo≈øt delicious fowl, that they are the ordinary food of a Pea≈øants Table in this Countrey; and at Buda at one Market-day have been ≈øold eight thou≈øand and ≈øix hundred Turtles: And be≈øides tho≈øe which are de≈øtroyed in the Kingdom it ≈øelf, there are ≈øome hundreds of Cartloads of wild fowl exported yearly out of Hungary into Au≈øtria, and other foreign Countreys. The Wines of Hungary are accounted as excellent as of any part ≈øoever, and as much valued at Vienna as the ≈øtronge≈øt Spani≈øh and Malaga; and particularly the Sirmian and Tokaiah, which are reckoned the riche≈øt of the Kingdom. The mo≈øt noted Mountain in the Realm of Hungary is Carpathus, under which General name are commonly comprehended all the Surmatian Hills, which ≈øeparate this Kingdom from Ru≈ø≈øia, Poland, Moravia, Sile≈øia, and ≈øome part of Au≈øtria. Out of the≈øe and their other Hills the Hungarians dig Gold, Silver, and other Metals. Be≈øides, this Countrey has ≈øeveral Fountains and Wells of ≈øtrange and wonderful qualities: Near the Town of Schm lnitz ≈øprings a noted Vitriol Water, which in a ≈øhort time turns great Plates of Iron into fine
Copper, which is thence tran≈øported into mo≈øt parts of Europe. There are ≈øeveral Waters in the Country of Zip, whereof if either Bea≈øt or Bird happen to ta≈øte, they dye immediately; and not far from Rau≈øchenbach, there is a fountain, which k ‚Ä¢ lls both the Cattle, and the Birds that come within the reach of its ≈øtreams. Hungary has on the We≈øt two great and famous Lakes, the one called Balaton, and is thirteen Gernian Miles in length, and the other Fewrtew. The mo≈øt con≈øiderable Rivers of this Countrey, is fir≈øt the Danube; ≈øecond the Tei≈øe, or Tabi≈øcus, which receives ≈øeveral others into it; third the Dravus, or Draab; fourth the Savus, or Sau: And the≈øe four Rivers quarter the Arms of Hungary, the ancient Kings con≈øidering them as the principal glory of their Dominions; and fifth Jaurinam, called by the Germans, Raab, and by Foreigners Areto and Narato; and the≈øe four la≈øt all fall into the Danube, which after it has run a cour≈øe of ≈øixteen hundred Engli≈øh miles, empties it ≈øelf into the Pontus Euximus.

The≈øe Rivers afford abundance o ‚Ä¢ Fi≈øh, e≈øpecially the Tei≈ø≈øe, in≈øomuch tha ‚Ä¢ it is a common ≈øaying, That divide the Tei≈ø≈øe into three parts, and one of them
will be Fi≈øh. A thou≈øand Carps have been known to have been ≈øold near the Banks of this River for le≈øs than an Engli≈øh Crown.

Hungary affords many Antiquities, and it is no hard matter to meet wich ancient Coins in that Countrey, that give the true Pourtraictures of Ly≈øimachus, Alexander the Great, Philip of Macedonia, Darius, Pergamus, Hercules, Milo, and other Ancient Heroes. Near the Town of Jeva the Pea≈øants found a mighty Trea≈øure of the≈øe Medals in Gold; which were di≈øcovered by a ≈øudden ru≈øhing torrent, the effect of a great ≈øhower. Each of the≈øe, to the number of many thou≈øands, weighed two or three Crowns; having on one ≈øide the image of Ly≈øimachus, and on the Rever≈øe Victoria. With the Medals was found a Golden Serpent: It being a cu≈øtome among≈øt the Ancients to bury a Serpent with their hid Trea≈øure, in token of a faithful keeper.

The Huns, before the Introduction of Chri≈øtianity, were a ≈øtrange barbarous and perver≈øe ≈øort of people. It was their cu≈øtome to fla≈øh the Cheeks of their young Infants, for the rendring their countenances the more terrible, ≈øo that when they came to age they re≈øembled ‚Ä¢
more the Antique Statues, and rude draughts of Faces carved on the ≈øides of Bridges, and other publick Fabricks, than Men. Their Education too was ≈øo hardy as not to ≈øtand in need of fire, either to warm them≈øelves or cook their meat; for all their meat was eaten either wholly raw, or otherwi≈øe ≈øleightly ≈øtewed betwixt the Riders Buttocks, and his Hor≈øes Back. Hou≈øes they never inhabited, nor ≈øo much as a ≈ølender Cottage or Hut of Wood or Ru≈øhes; but were from their Cradles brought up in the Fore≈øts and Mountains. Their apparel was u≈øually the skins of Wild Bea≈øts, which they never put off until they ≈øell away in rags. They never dwelt in any one certain place, nor troubled them≈øelves to till or improve the land. They had no ≈øen≈øe of Morality, no ob≈øervers of their Leagues and Promi≈øes with other Nations, exerci≈øed no Religious Act, making their Swords, and other Warlike Engines, their only Divinities. But the Huns at this day are much different in manners from their Barbarous Ance≈øtors. They have ≈øhewn them≈øelves in their age a Warlike and Politick people, and zealous a≈ø≈øertors of the Religion they profe≈øs; they are generally
lazy, but that may be attributed to the fertility of the Countrey. They are Gluttons, but the Gentry are commonly per≈øons of great Humanity, Gravity, and Parts; but are neverthele≈øs Ambitious and Popular, and cannot well brook a Monarchical Sway. Their habits in Winter are clo≈øe-bodied Coats, with a loo≈øe Cloak, button'd or clapp'd over their left ≈øhoulder, and under their right pap, ≈øo as that they have their right hand at liberty. They wear generally a girdle of what colour they plea≈øe, folded about their middle. The Gentry affect mo≈øt a Red Coloured Silk or Velvet; the Citizens Red or Blue Cloath; and the Pea≈øants are commonly clad in a cour≈øe Cloath, either of a Green, or one of the fore-mentioned Colours. The young men fancy the feathers of an Eagle, Hawk, Kite or any other Bird of prey, a mighty ornament in their Bonnets. The Hungarian Women do now ≈øomething imitate the Germans, and other Europeans in their apparel, only they wear a ≈øhort Cloak or Mantle thrown over their ≈øhouldes, which they ≈øtill retain, how often ≈øoever they change the mode of their other apparel: They generally wear a Veil over the Mouth
and No≈øe. The Hungarians ≈øhave their Heads, but wear their Beards to a great length; and this they do, thinking perhaps thereby to render them≈øelves the more terrible to their Enemies. The Hungarians tell of one of their Countreymen, who had a Beard of that prodigious length (in the Wars again≈øt the Turks) that it ≈øerved him for a Girdle by day, and at night in≈øtead of a Coverlid for his whole Body. And in the time of his ≈øervice, the whole Regiment being commanded to be ≈øhaved, he was exempted, proffering to lay down his life rather than part with this venerable ornament. Batchelours ≈øhave their Chins, but wear Mu≈øtachoes on their upper lips.

The Hungarian Tongue is peculiar to the Natives of this Kingdom, having no Affinity with any other ≈øpoken in the Neighbouring Provinces. There is ≈øuch a re≈øemblance in the Pr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nunciation of this with the Hebrew Language, that ≈øhould the Hungarians make u≈øe of the Jewi≈øh Characters, all the ≈øeveral points and accents which are u≈øed in the Hebrew, might be found very u≈øeful in writing the Hungarian. Neverthele≈øs, the Hungarians are ≈øo generally brought up to
expre≈øs them≈øelves in the Latin Tongue, that every Pea≈øant is capable of giving an intelligible an≈øwer in Latin, which is of more u≈øe to a Traveller in Hungary and Tran≈øylvania, than in any other Countrey of the World. A man may travel from Hamburg to the Borders of Tartary, and to Con≈øtantinople, without making u≈øe of any other language than the High-Dutch and Sclavonian; which latter enters about Belgrade, and is ≈øpoken in Servia, Bulgaria, Romania, and a great part of Macedonia. The Europeans generally begin their lines from the left, and write towards the right hand; the A≈øians contrariwi≈øe from right to left: only the Hungarian ‚Ä¢
and Tran≈øylvanians draw their lines from the top of the Page to the bottome. At pre≈øent the whole Nation make u≈øe of the Latin Alphabet, borrowing only from the Greeks (as the Engli≈øh do k and y.) Many men of Learning cannot be expected in ≈øuch a Martial Countrey, though it produced S. Hierom and S. Martin, but they had their Education out of the Kingdom, as have mo≈øt per≈øons of Quality at this day. But had the≈øe People had the lei≈øure or di≈øpo≈øition to apply them≈øelves to learning, they might had great advantages of improvement
from the Noble Library erected at Buda, by their King Mathius Corvinus, about two hundred years ago. But the≈øe after the Surpri≈øing of that Town, by Solyman the Magnificent, were di≈øpers'd into the Turki≈øh Dominions and other Parts, and what remained de≈øtroyed by the Fire that happened there in 1669.

Before that Chri≈øtianity was planted in Hungary, the≈øe people, as mo≈øt other Barbarous Nations, own'd no ≈øubjection to any certain Prince; but only by an unanimous con≈øent, ≈øubjected them≈øelves to the Government of a Ruler or Captain, who was to direct and command the re≈øt, in the time of War or in other ca≈øes extraordinary. Nay, and even after the Introduction of Chri≈øtianity, Hungary was no Kingdom, nor Governed by any ≈øelf kind of Laws, before the twelfth Century; though ≈øome affirm, that during the time of Pagani≈øm, the Land was ≈øwayed by fourteen Dukes ≈øucce≈ø≈øively with Monarchical Juri≈ødiction. But to come to this time; though the Kingdom of Hungary is pretended to be Elective, yet ≈øtill a Title to the Crown was pretended by all its Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors, how faintly ≈øoever made out. Nor will they, the Hungarians, allow but that their
Crown is independant, notwith≈øtanding the homages that have been done by their Princes to the German Emperours, and the Tributes they have paid the Turks, which they call Pen≈øions.

The Ceremonies antiently ob≈øerved of the King of Hungary, was the A≈ø≈øembling of the Bi≈øhops and Nobles, the Deputies, of the ≈øeveral Counties, Cities, &c. in a certain Place near Pae≈øt, where after the Palatine had pre≈øented the Prince to the People, and three times obtained their A≈ø≈øent, he put a Naked Sword into the King's hand; who was to ≈øhake it Ea≈øt, We≈øt, North, and South. The≈øe and other u≈øual Rites being performed, that are ob≈øerved at the Coronation of a Chri≈øtian King, he was re-conducted in great Pomp to his Palace: The Crown of Hungary is had in great Veneration with that People; they believing that the Fate of their Kingdom depends upon the Careful Pre≈øervation of it; and in the ≈øevere≈øt Streights and Calamities that can befall them, they are ≈øure to take Care for its Security in the fir≈øt place.

The Chief Revenues of the Crown ari≈øe from the Berg-T ‚Ä¢ wns, and the Mines of Silver, and other Mettals, whence the King is ≈øaid Yearly to have One Hundred and Sixty Thou≈øand Rix-Dollars. The other great Branch of his Revenue ≈øprings from the Impo≈øt upon Cattle, and is reckoned at Thirty Thou≈øand Ducats. The≈øe and other le≈øs con≈øiderable Advantages afford his Imperial Maje≈øty, as King of Hungary; Two Hundred, Twenty and Four Thou≈øand Ducats, Yearly, which amount to One Hundred and Twelve Thou≈øand Pound Sterling, Engli≈øh Money.
